Description: Introduction to digital and technological cultures with a focus on humanities methods, drawing on a range of periods in technological development and critical approaches to studying technology. At least 35% of class involves practice-based instruction in humanities criticism, prototyping, writing and research.

Name: DIHU 220 Research with Media in the Humanities
Description: Working in the context of fine arts and humanities research, students develop methods for multimedia research. No digital humanities or computing experience required. At least 35% of class time involves instruction in humanities criticism, prototyping, writing, and research. Credit will be granted for only one of DIHU 220 and CULT 220.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (3 credits of 100-level CULT, DIHU, or ENGL, or FILM 100)

Name: DIHU 302 The Programmed World
Description: Working in the context of fine arts and humanities research, students study and apply programming principles in physical and virtual environments. No Digital Humanities or computing experience required. Credit will be granted for only one of DIHU 302 or ENGL 306.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (3 credits of 100-level CULT, DIHU, ENGL, or FILM 100 and third-year standing.)

Name: DIHU 312A Internet Culture - INTERNET CULT
Description: A critical study of the cultural influence of the Internet on everyday life. With different topics, this course may be taken more than once for credit. No more than 9 credits in total will be granted for DIHU 312, CULT 312, or any combination thereof. Credit will be granted for only one of DIHU 312 and CULT 312 when the subject matter is of the same nature.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: DIHU 370 Story and Image Across the Islamic World
Description: Selections from the arts of the book across the Islamic world (8th to 19th C) showing how literature inspired painters and calligraphers to weave together word and image. Digital art historical approaches will normally be used, though no computing experience is required. Credit will be granted for only one of DIHU 370, ARTH 370, or WRLD 370.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: EADM 556 Conceptualizing Leadership
Description: Broad conceptualization of leadership for learning organizations, communities, and enterprises through an examination of the historical, philosophical, theoretical, and ethical foundations of leadership.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MED-O

Name: EAP 103 English for Academic Purposes Level III
Description: Practice and refinement of academic communication and composition skills: writing and grammar; reading comprehension and proficiency; listening comprehension and oral fluency; intercultural communication. Students participate in an increasingly complex variety of academic activities and situations involving multiple purposes and participants. Twelve weeks (240 hours).
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Minimum English language competence level (see English Language Proficiency Tests at https://okanagan.calendar.ubc.ca/admissions/english-language-admission-standard/english-language-proficiency-tests-and-programs). Registration limited to students in the English Foundation Program.)

Name: EAP 104 English for Academic Purposes Level IV
Description: Development of advanced academic communication and composition skills: writing and grammar; reading comprehension and proficiency; comprehension and oral fluency; intercultural communication. Students participate in a variety of complex academic activities and situations involving multiple purposes and participants. Twelve weeks (240 hours).
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Successful completion of EAP 103 or minimum English language competence level (see English Language Proficiency Tests at https://okanagan.calendar.ubc.ca/admissions/english-language-admission-standard/english-language-proficiency-tests-and-programs). Registration limited to students in the English Foundation Program.)

Name: ECED 440 Play and Early Childhood Education
Description: Examines the key issues, practices, philosophies, and research findings that explore childhood play as it is integrated into formal learning. Pass/Fail.

Name: ECED 445 Social Equality and Early Learning
Description: Examines socio-economic and community factors in early child development and learning that influence healthy child development. Pass/Fail.

Name: ECON 101 Principles of Microeconomics
Description: Elements of theory and Canadian policy and institutions concerning the economics of markets and market behaviour, prices and costs, exchange and trade, competition and monopoly, distribution of income.

Name: ECON 102 Principles of Macroeconomics
Description: Elements of theory and Canadian policy and institutions concerning the economics of growth and business cycles, national income accounting, interest and exchange rates, money and banking, the balance of trade.

Name: ECON 204 Intermediate Microeconomic Analysis
Description: Microtheory course at the post-principles level. Analysis of consumer behaviour, production, exchange, equilibrium of the firm under varying market structures, factor markets, economic efficiency, and welfare.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: ECON 101 and one of MATH 100, MATH 116.

Name: ECON 205 Intermediate Macroeconomic Analysis
Description: Macrotheory course at the post-principles level. Income and employment theory, monetary and fiscal policies, the impact of international trade and finance on the domestic economy, economic growth and fluctuations.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: ECON 102 and one of MATH 100, MATH 116.

Name: ECON 221 Introduction to Strategic Thinking
Description: Game theory with applications drawn from many disciplines and the principles of strategic interactions.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102.

Name: ECON 225 Data and Statistics for Economics
Description: Visualization and interpretation of economic data. Topics include descriptive statistics, graphical methods, and inference, and applying these methods to economic data. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 225 or ECON 391M.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ECON 101, ECON 102.

Name: ECON 232 History of Economic Thought
Description: Evolution of economic thinking from ancient to present times. The Greek, Islamic, and Medieval scholars; the Physiocrats, Adam Smith, Malthus, Bentham, Ricardo, Mill, Marx, Keynes, and other major economic thinkers. Development of fundamental economic ideas and conflicting perspectives are studied within their social and economic context.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102.

Name: ECON 295 Managerial Economics
Description: Economic foundations of managerial decision-making. Demand theory, cost and production, market structure, competitive strategy, organization of the firm, welfare-economic foundations of business regulation.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102.

Name: ECON 308 Intermediate Microeconomics II
Description: Factor markets, general equilibrium, uncertainty and information, contract theory, externalities, public goods, and welfare.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: ECON 204.

Name: ECON 320 Introduction to Mathematical Economics
Description: Application of single and multivariable calculus to economics. Includes comparative static analysis of household and firm behaviour as well as simple dynamic models.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102 and one of MATH 101, MATH 142.

Name: ECON 327 Introduction to Empirical Economics
Description: The essentials of probability and statistics for applied work in economics. Topics include descriptive statistics, probability, estimation, hypothesis testing, and analysis of variance.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102, ECON 225 and one of MATH 101, MATH 142.

Name: ECON 328 Methods of Empirical Research
Description: Techniques of empirical economic research. Simple and multiple regression, time series analysis, and simultaneous equation estimation. Students are required to undertake applied work.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: ECON 327.

Name: ECON 331 World Economy since 1800
Description: Development of the world economy, from the onset of the Industrial Revolution around 1800 to the present. Broad causes of world economic development, interaction between economic forces and social institutions, and development of particular national economies.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102.

Name: ECON 339 Economics of Technological Change
Description: Application of economic analysis to technological change; impact of technological change on the growth and distribution of income; economic influences on the invention and diffusion of technology; interaction between technology, work, skills, and education; public policy toward technological change.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102.

Name: ECON 340 Financial Economics
Description: Fundamental topics in financial economics, including net present value, risk and expected return, valuing bonds and equities, the capital asset pricing model, futures and options, and international investing.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102.

Name: ECON 345 Money and Banking
Description: Financial markets and financial institutions in theory and practice; structure and development of the Canadian financial system; development and theory of the regulation of the financial system; process of monetary control; theory and history of central banking and monetary policy.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102.

Name: ECON 347 Monetary Economics
Description: Monetary theory and practice. Demand for money. Goals, strategies and tools of central banks. Theory and practice of the interactions between money and other economic variables. Recent policy issues, such as digital currency. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 347 or ECON 391W.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102.

Name: ECON 351 Women in the Economy
Description: Economic analysis of markets and policies particularly affecting women. Economic discrimination; educational, occupational, and work choices; pay and employment equity; allocation of work time; household and market consumption; economics of marriage and fertility; poverty; taxation; income security and pension policies; and historical perspectives.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102.

Name: ECON 352 Public Sector Economics
Description: The government plays a pervasive role in the Canadian economy. The powerful tools of government policy - taxation, spending, borrowing, and regulation - affect the economic life of every Canadian. This course applies the tools of economic analysis to the study of some of the most important aspects of public policy in these areas.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102.

Name: ECON 355 International Trade
Description: The determinants of trade patterns, trade policy, tariff and non-tariff barriers to trade, political economy of protectionism, bilateral and multilateral trade disputes, trade liberalization, trade and development.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102.

Name: ECON 356 International Finance
Description: Exchange rate policy regimes; international financial organizations; the interaction between monetary policy and exchange rate regimes; financial crises.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102.

Name: ECON 360 Labour Economics
Description: Canadian labour market. Labour supply, allocation of time among work and non-market activity, labour force participation, education and training. Determination of and effect of unions on wages and employment. Wage structure and differentials.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102.

Name: ECON 361 Economics of Industrial Relations
Description: Economic aspects of industrial relations in Canada; why workers join unions; theory of trade union behaviour; labour movement in Canada; wage determination under collective bargaining; causes of strikes and lockouts; unions and wage structure.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102.

Name: ECON 363 Health Economics
Description: The role of economics in health, healthcare, and health policy. Topics include economic determinants of health, minority health and health equity, health economic evaluation, demand for healthcare and health insurance, health risk behaviours, and public policy and health outcomes. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 363 or ECON 391V.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 225.

Name: ECON 370 Benefit-Cost Analysis and the Economics of Project Evaluation
Description: Techniques and problems in benefit-cost analysis of public projects. Examination of alternative approaches to public decision-making such as cost-effectiveness analysis and multiple-objective frameworks. Case studies of projects in the areas of natural resources, the environment, human resources, public services, and transportation.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ENGR 305.

Name: ECON 371 Economics of the Environment
Description: Economic analysis applied to various environmental issues, including sustainable development, quality of life, and environmental impacts of specific industrial and consumption activities. The design and implementation of government policies. Global environmental effects of human economic activity.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102.

Name: ECON 386 Industrial Organization and Regulation
Description: Survey of the behaviour and performance of firms. Determinants and measures of market structure, oligopoly theory, strategic behaviour, predation, entry deterrence, advertising, regulation, and competition policy.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102, ECON 204.

Name: ECON 391B Topics in Economics - FUTURE OF WORK
Description: Examination of selected topics in current economic theory and/or policy. Topics vary each time the course is offered. With different topics, the course can be taken more than once for credit.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102.

Name: ECON 391N Topics in Economics - ECON DEVELOPMENT
Description: Examination of selected topics in current economic theory and/or policy. Topics vary each time the course is offered. With different topics, the course can be taken more than once for credit.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102.

Name: ECON 391X Topics in Economics - DYNMCS ECON
Description: Examination of selected topics in current economic theory and/or policy. Topics vary each time the course is offered. With different topics, the course can be taken more than once for credit.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102.

Name: ECON 391Y Topics in Economics - LAW & ECON
Description: Examination of selected topics in current economic theory and/or policy. Topics vary each time the course is offered. With different topics, the course can be taken more than once for credit.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102.

Name: ECON 401 Applied Microeconomic Analysis
Description: Advanced analysis of consumer theory, market supply and demand, competition, general equilibrium, the theory of the firm, and the economics of information and uncertainty.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: ECON 204 and one of MATH 100, MATH 116 and one of MATH 101, MATH 142. (and third-year standing.)

Name: ECON 402 Applied Macroeconomic Analysis
Description: Advanced treatment of the core topics in macroeconomics such as the business cycle, inflation, unemployment, growth, alternative exchange rate regimes, and fiscal and monetary policy.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: ECON 205 and one of MATH 100, MATH 116 and one of MATH 101, MATH 142. (and third-year standing.)

Name: ECON 409 Economic Growth Theory
Description: Advanced topics in economic growth theory and their applications to Real Business Cycle theory. Topics include exogenous and endogenous growth theory, Neoclassical and New Classical growth theory.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ECON 204, ECON 205 and one of MATH 100, MATH 116. (and third-year standing.)

Name: ECON 427 Econometrics
Description: Advanced treatment of estimation, inference, and econometric problems and techniques with focus on both theoretical and applied methods and with application to a variety of economic models..
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: ECON 328. (or 3 credits of ECON and 3 credits of upper-level STAT.)

Name: ECON 495 Honours Seminar
Description: Reports and group discussions of selected topics for fourth-year Honours students. Development of a research proposal.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Admission to the B.A. or B.Sc. Economics Honours Program)

Name: ECON 497 Directed Studies for PPE Major
Description: Supervised investigation of an assigned topic in public policy. Requires a significant amount of independent reading and analysis, and production of a major term paper at the end of the course.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=4 with one of these specializations: MAJ PPE
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Fourth-year standing in the PPE Major program with an emphasis in Economics (option A) and permission of the instructor.)

Name: ECON 499 Honours Essay
Description: Essay on some theoretical, applied, or institutional problem and a formal presentation of the findings.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: ECON 495.

Name: EDST 498Y Contemporary Educational Practice - EXPL INCLV TEACH
Description: Seminar that explores various approaches, projects, methodologies, and teaching applications. Pass/Fail.

Name: EDUC 100 Controversial Issues in Education
Description: Students will examine basic and fundamental questions about educational policy and practice by critically examining a variety of controversial issues including, but not limited to, issues of equality, community, and individual rights and freedoms.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Students must have one of a) 70% in English 12 or English 12 First Peoples; b) a 5 on the LPI; c) a passing grade in ENGL 009; d) or an acceptable equivalent. For a list of equivalency options consult the Current Students website at students.ok.ubc.ca/courses-money-enrolment/registration/first-year-english/ .)

Name: EDUC 104 Introduction to Academic Pedagogy: An Aboriginal Perspective
Description: Using an Aboriginal approach to the cycle of learning, this developmental course provides an opportunity for first-year students to learn essential skills needed for academic success.

Name: EDUC 160 Mathematical Reasoning for Arts and Education
Description: For Arts and prospective Education students who wish to gain a deeper understanding of mathematics. Using the approach of problem solving and logical reasoning throughout, topics are chosen from discrete mathematics, elementary number theory, probability and statistics, measurement and geometry, linear algebra, and applications. Credit will only be granted for one of MATH 160 or EDUC 160. Cannot be used for credit toward a B.Sc. or B.M.S. degree, or for the B.A. Major in Mathematics program.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Foundations of Mathematics 11 or Pre-calculus 11)

Name: EDUC 300 Inquiry in Education
Description: An introduction to the distinctive manner in which core concepts and methods of scholarly inquiry are applied to education as a field of inquiry. Through a variety of hands-on learning activities, readings, seminars, discussions, and personal reflection students will explore the processes and products of inquiry.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: EDUC 100. (Or third-year standing)

Name: EDUC 400 Designing and Facilitating Effective Learning Experiences
Description: Leverage evidence based principles, approaches, methods, and strategies to design and facilitate effective learning experiences.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: EDUC 100. (Or third-year standing)

Name: EDUC 403 Becoming a Scholar-Practitioner
Description: The cultivation of knowledge and understanding regarding the interdisciplinary foundations of educational principles, policies and practices, all of which are examined through large group contexts, seminars and field experiences. Pass/Fail.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Restricted to students in the Bachelor of Education Program)

Name: EDUC 431 Developing a Pedagogical Stance
Description: Foundational pedagogical knowledge and practice explored through seminars, colloquia and site-based learning where teacher candidates develop their practice and understandings related to diversity, literacies, numeracy and learning theories. Pass/Fail.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: EDUC 403.

Name: EDUC 436 Developing Curricular Vision for a Democratic Society: Educational Purposes, Policies, and Practices, Part I
Description: Examines the nature of curriculum focusing on the humanities and languages. Opportunities and challenges of developing curriculum for schooling are considered within contemporary political, legal, moral, administrative, and policy contexts. Pass/Fail.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of EDUC 431, EDUC 440.

Name: EDUC 438 Educating for the Whole Person
Description: Teaching and learning theory and practice relating to a holistic approach to well-being. Examining and interpreting the research on philosophical, psychological, physiological and political aspects of wellbeing. Pass/Fail.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: EDUC 441.

Name: EDUC 440 Field Experience: Literacies and Numeracies in Action
Description: Foundational pedagogical knowledge and practice will be explored through school-based inquiry. With a focus on literacies and numeracies in action, teacher candidates will work with mentor teachers in weekly school visits and then complete a minor practicum. Mentor teachers will take the lead in planning and curriculum enactment while the teacher candidate observes, works with individuals or small groups, and conducts teaching responsibilities as deemed fitting. Pass/Fail.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Restricted to students in the Bachelor of Education Program)

Name: EDUC 441 Field Experience: Formative Practicum
Description: Working collaboratively in a school context, mentor teachers and teacher candidates co-plan, co-teach and co-assess. Insight into the significance of personal practical knowledge by engaging in dialogue, observation, and reflection concerning why the mentor teacher orients practices in particular ways, using specific strategies, resources, and lesson sequences. Pass/Fail.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of EDUC 440, EDUC 431.

Name: EDUC 444 Field Experience: Final Practicum/Internship
Description: Extended immersion in a school community, co-planning/co-teaching/co-assessing with mentors and other colleagues and, with demonstrated competency, assume the lead in planning and curricular enactment with the support of mentor teachers. Pass/Fail.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (EDUC 438, 6 credits of electives or equivalent approved by the Faculty of Education.)

Name: EDUC 500 Research Methodology in Education Part I
Description: An introductory course examining various issues, methods and techniques used in educational research. Consideration is given to research strategies and techniques and the selection of research questions appropriate to a range of issues facing educators.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MED-O

Name: EDUC 517G Contemporary Issues in Education - NAV EDUC CNTRVSY
Description: Examination of a range of issues impacting education in provincial, national, and global perspectives. Socio/cultural issues, politics and educational policy, violence and safety, impact of technology on teaching and learning, and preparation of educators in a changing culture.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MED-O,MENG-O,MFA-O,MA-O,MASC-O,MFA-O,MM-O,MMUS,MSC-O,MSN-O,MSW-O,PHD-O

Name: EDUC 526 Education and Diversity
Description: Overview of current diversity theory and practice. Focuses on the social construction of differences, the theoretical underpinnings of diversity, and oppression theory/practice in a Canadian and world educational context with an emphasis on language, culture, and society.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MED-O

Name: EDUC 529 Building Communities: Education Beyond the Classroom
Description: The intent of this course is to explore the systemic factors of education in conjunction with its communities and other organizations so that the student will be well versed, practically and theoretically, to engage in education as a "whole."
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MED-O,MA-O

Name: EDUC 534 Coyote Stories: Pedagogy and Praxis
Description: Examines how respective Indigenous traditional knowledge stories and storytelling practices inform organic theoretical frameworks, pedagogy, and praxis in place-based schooling, community, and peoples transforming projects. Credit will be granted for only one of EDUC 534 and EDUC 562 when the subject matter is of the same nature.

Name: EDUC 560A Directed Studies in Education - WLD FRFGHT RESLC
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MED-O

Name: EDUC 560C Directed Studies in Education - PLC-BSD LRN SYLX
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MED-O

Name: EDUC 560G Directed Studies in Education - LND BSD LRN INDG
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MED-O

Name: EDUC 560M Directed Studies in Education - EDUC PBLIC SPHR
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MED-O

Name: EDUC 598 M.Ed. Seminar with Project
Description: Building on coursework completed during the master's program, this course supports students in the development of their M.Ed. exit projects. It provides scaffolding for the conceptualization, development, and completion of projects that will meet or exceed the requirements for both graduate programs and teacher qualification standards. Pass/Fail.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MED-O

Name: EDUC 599 Senior Seminar with Thesis
Description: Pass/Fail.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O with one of these specializations: ****EDUC

Name: EESC 101 Environmental Science
Description: A quantitative and scientific approach to the understanding of global energy, water and nutrient cycling; growth of human populations and their effects on the environment and ecosystem function. Functional understanding of modern environmental issues, and the requirements of, and opportunities for, sustainability.

Name: EESC 104 Four Billion Years and Counting
Description: The geological history of what is now Canada from the formation of Earth to the present day. Practical applications of geology to Canadian society and the economy.

Name: EESC 106 The Catastrophic Earth
Description: The causes, physical characteristics, and consequences of natural disasters such as earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, severe weather, landslides, tsunamis, floods, meteor impact, and mass extinctions.

Name: EESC 111 Earth Science
Description: Origin, structure and composition of Earth. Plate tectonics as the unifying mechanism for mountain building, formation of ocean basins, and assembly and break-up of continents. Minerals, rocks, Earth surface processes, geological maps, natural resources and hazards.

Name: EESC 112 Environmental Earth Science
Description: Earth systems and environment: atmosphere, climate, water cycle, oceans, surface water, groundwater, earth surface processes, soils, and biogeochemical cycling. Applications of environmental science to solving modern environmental problems.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: EESC 111 and one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121.

Name: EESC 121 Earth History
Description: Origin of rocks, oceans, atmosphere and the record of life on Earth. Scientific methods of studying Earth history. Geologic time, dating methods, the stratigraphic record. Organic evolution, the fossil record, and extinctions.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (EESC 111 recommended.)

Name: EESC 200 Mineralogy
Description: Crystallography and the physical and chemical properties of minerals. Recognition and identification of common minerals.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: EESC 111 and one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121.

Name: EESC 201 Optical Mineralogy and Petrology
Description: Identification of common rock-forming minerals using the polarizing microscope. Use of minerals and rock textures as a means of determining the classification and petrogenesis of igneous and metamorphic rocks.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of EESC 111, EESC 200.

Name: EESC 205 Introduction to Hydrology
Description: Principles of hydrology at site, watershed, and regional scales. Techniques of measurement and analysis. Emphasizes surface water hydrology of western North America. Credit will be granted for only one of EESC 205 or GEOG 205.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) two of EESC 101, EESC 111, EESC 121 or (b) all of GEOG 108, GEOG 109. (or (c) second-year standing in the Bachelor of Science.)

Name: EESC 212 Atmospheric Environments
Description: Physical principles underlying weather and climates. Thermal, moisture, and wind climates at scales from valleys to the globe. Daily weather, air pollution, global change. Credit will be granted for only one of EESC 212 or GEOG 200.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) GEOG 108 and GEOG 109; or (b) two of EESC 101, EESC 111, EESC 121. (or (c) second-year standing in the Bachelor of Science.)

Name: EESC 213 Introductory Forest Science and Management
Description: Global forests, classification, silviculture, forest tenure systems, forest policy evolution, forest regulations, and the profession. Overview of forest disturbance impacts, eco-forestry, sustainable forest management, eco-certification, the role of information technologies and research.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) two of BIOL 125, EESC 101, EESC 111, GEOG 108, GEOG 109 or (b) two of BIOL 125, EESC 111, GEOG 108, GEOG 109, SUST 100 or (c) one of BIOL 201, BIOL 210, GEOG 207.

Name: EESC 222 Geomorphology
Description: Landform assemblages and processes of landscape evolution on Earth. Fundamental concepts, including system equilibrium, thresholds, complex response to external forces, and scale dependency, with application to mountains, rivers, coasts, and glaciated terrain. Laboratory exercises require field work in lab time. Required one-day, weekend trip. Credit will be granted for only one of EESC 222 or GEOG 222.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) GEOG 108 and GEOG 109; or (b) MATH 100 and EESC 111. (or (c) second-year standing in the Bachelor of Science.)

Name: EESC 303 Oceanography
Description: Geological, chemical, physical and biological oceanography using a multi-disciplinary approach. Origins of oceans, plate tectonics and ocean basins, marine sediments, physical properties and composition of seawater, ocean-atmosphere interactions, surface and deep currents, waves, tides, primary productivity, pelagic and benthic ecosystems, methods of ocean investigation.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) two of EESC 101, EESC 111, EESC 121, GEOG 108, GEOG 109 or (b) one of EESC 301, BIOL 307, CHEM 301, EESC 309. (Third-year standing.)

Name: EESC 304 Anthropogenic Climate Change
Description: Mechanisms of anthropogenic climate change and its impact on the atmosphere, hydrosphere, cryosphere, and oceans since the Industrial Revolution. Use of computer models to forecast 21st century climate changes. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 304 or EESC 304.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of GEOG 108, GEOG 200, EESC 212. (Third-year standing.)

Name: EESC 309 Global Biogeochemistry
Description: Functional processes and reactions of our living planet. Cycles of materials and energy among the atmosphere, lithosphere, and terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems. Case studies on the degradation of ecosystem function from anthropogenic alterations of natural cycles.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of CHEM 113, CHEM 123 and either (a) two of EESC 101, EESC 111, EESC 121 or (b) all of GEOG 108, GEOG 109 or (c) one of BIOL 201, BIOL 203 or (d) one of CHEM 301, CHEM 302.

Name: EESC 313 Management of Forested Watersheds
Description: Effects of watershed management on water quality and quantity, channel morphology, in-stream wood, and aquatic habitat. Emphasizing integrated land use management and the maintenance of critical watershed functions and services.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of EESC 111, EESC 213, GEOG 108, GEOG 109. (Third-year standing.)

Name: EESC 314 Environmental Impact Assessment: Process, Regulation and Administration
Description: Legal, administrative and project management aspects of environmental impact assessment (EIA). EIA regulations, processes and systems. Assessment approaches and methods for cumulative effects, social/economic impacts, strategic and regional assessment, risk assessment and public participation. Canadian federal, territorial and provincial EIA systems. Credit will be granted for only one of EESC 314 or GEOG 314
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Either (a) 6 credits of EESC or (b) 6 credits of GEOG. Third-year standing.)

Name: EESC 315 Environmental Impact Assessment: Techniques and practice
Description: Practical techniques and methods for environmental impact assessment. Technical approaches, evaluation and estimation tools, and project management skills used for environmental assessment work.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Either (a) 6 credits of EESC or (b) 6 credits of GEOG. Third-year standing. EESC/GEOG 314 is recommended.)

Name: EESC 322 Igneous and Metamorphic Petrology
Description: Description, classification, and petrogenesis of igneous and metamorphic rocks. Igneous and metamorphic processes. Past and present plate tectonic implications.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: EESC 201.

Name: EESC 323 Geochemistry
Description: Origin, distribution, and cycles of elements in Earth. Low-temperature aqueous solution chemistry, fluid-rock interaction, mineral stability, isotopes.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of EESC 111, EESC 200, GEOG 109, CHEM 201, CHEM 210 and either (a) CHEM 113 or (b) CHEM 123.

Name: EESC 325 Structural Geology
Description: Description and classification of geologic structures. Stress, strain and their relationship to deformation processes. Mechanics of faulting, folding, and shear zone development. Interpretation of physical deformation processes and the resulting geologic structures.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: BSC-O in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: EESC 111. (and Third-year standing in EESc Major or EESc Minor.)

Name: EESC 342 Hydrogeology
Description: Introduction to the theory of groundwater flow; flow nets; regional groundwater resource evaluation; well hydraulics.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) MATH 100 and one of PHYS 111, PHYS 112 and one of EESC 111, EESC 121, GEOG 109, EESC 205, GEOG 205; or (b) one of ENGR 340, ENGR 341. (Third-year standing.)

Name: EESC 350 Geophysics
Description: Instrumentation, application, and limitations of gravity, magnetic, electromagnetic, electrical and seismic methods in the exploration for mineral and energy resources and in environmental and engineering applications.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) one of MATH 101, MATH 103 and one of EESC 111, EESC 121 and one of PHYS 121, PHYS 122; or (b) ENGR 340. (Third-year standing.)

Name: EESC 356 Stratigraphy and Sedimentology
Description: Origin, classification and interpretation of sediments and sedimentary rocks. Weathering, erosion, transportation, sedimentation, and lithification of clastic materials. Non-clastic sediments. Sedimentary environments, facies and stratigraphic methods. Credit will be granted for only one of EESC 356 or GEOG 356.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of EESC 121, EESC 222, GEOG 222.

Name: EESC 360 Geologic Resources
Description: Mineral deposits, their geologic settings, genetic classification and models of formation. Metalliferous, non-metalliferous and industrial materials deposits.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: EESC 200 and EESC 201.

Name: EESC 367 Energy Resources Management
Description: Key energy systems and resources management from both global and Canadian perspectives. Supplies, distribution, consumption, resilience and sustainability of energy resources. Alternative energy sources, conventional and unconventional fossil fuels, energy production and delivery systems. Credit will be granted for only one of EESC 367 or GEOG 367.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of GEOG 108, GEOG 129, EESC 101, EESC 111. (Third-year standing)

Name: EESC 398 Technical Communication
Description: Written and oral communication. Report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation of technical material. Advanced grammar and writing styles. Logical writing; referencing; and editing. Presenting technical information to scientists and non-scientists.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Three credits of APSC 176, CORH 203, ENGL 109,112, 113, 114, 150, 151, 153, 154, 155, or 156.)

Name: EESC 402 Freshwater Resources
Description: Integrated approach to freshwater resources and their place in environmental science. Topical issues with emphasis on management options and consequences. Required field trips during lab times.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (3 credits of 200-level courses in BIOL, CHEM, EESC or GEOG courses cross listed with EESC, and third-year standing.)

Name: EESC 413 Analytical Methods in Hydrology
Description: Application of advanced analytical methods to hydrological data for watershed or water resource planning and management. Frequency analysis, storm design, regionalization, flow routing, geographic information systems (GIS) application, time series analysis and modelling.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of GEOG 271, ENGR 360, BIOL 202, STAT 121, STAT 230 and one of EESC 205, GEOG 205, ENGR 341, ENGR 342. (and third-year standing.)

Name: EESC 423 Tracers of Natural Processes
Description: Stable and radiogenic isotopes in the lithosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere and biosphere. Fractionation processes, dating methods. Selected topics in the use of isotopic tracers.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: EESC 111 and one of CHEM 113, CHEM 123. (Third year standing.)

Name: EESC 425 Tectonics and Orogenesis
Description: Large-scale Earth structure, tectonic environments, Archean geology and the initiation of plate tectonics. Analytical toolsets. Orogenesis within the Canadian Cordillera, the Andes, the Alps, and the Himalaya.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: EESC 323 and EESC 325.

Name: EESC 431 Quaternary Glacial Environments
Description: Origin, nature, and distribution of glacial landforms and landform assemblages. Evaluation of hypotheses and theories on formation of glacial landforms and sediments, glacial mechanics, hydrology, and Quaternary stratigraphy. Students are required to attend several field trips on weekends.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of EESC 222, EESC 356, GEOG 222, GEOG 356.

Name: EESC 449 Honours Thesis
Description: Students undertake an individual research project as agreed upon by the student and the supervising faculty member. A written thesis is required and the research must be publicly presented as a seminar or poster.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Admission to the Earth and Environmental Sciences or Freshwater Sciences Honours program.)

Name: EESC 512 Applied Data Analysis in Geosciences
Description: Quantitative analytical methods used in data-rich branches of geosciences including: data acquisition, mining and quality assessment; data transformation strategies; data representation and pattern discovery; and alternative data models. Practical problem solving.

Name: EESC 550 Research in Earth and Environmental Sciences
Description: Practical and theoretical grounding in professional research. Critical assessment of the logic, reasoning, and structure of research ideas. Research proposal development. Presentation of scientific ideas in written and oral forms. Seminar presentations by faculty and external speakers, as available.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MASC-O,MED-O,MENG-O,MFA-O,MM-O,MSC-O,MSN-O,MSW-O,PHD-O

Name: EESC 560 Graduate Seminar
Description: Students present a public lecture about a topic jointly decided upon with the instructor and/or supervisory committee. Students will be assessed on their seminar and a companion paper.

Name: EESC 599 M.Sc. Thesis
Description: Pass/Fail.

Name: EESC 699 Ph.D. Dissertation
Description: Pass/Fail.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MASC-O,MED-O,MENG-O,MFA-O,MM-O,MSC-O,MSN-O,MSW-O,PHD-O

Name: ENGL 104 University Writing: Indigenous Perspectives
Description: Advances communication skills in composition, close reading, rhetoric, grammar, and citation. Emphasis on academic literacy from Indigenous perspectives. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGL 104 or ENGL 109. Restricted to students in the Aboriginal Access Studies program and/or students who self-identify as Indigenous in the Student Service Centre (SSC).

Name: ENGL 109 Studies in Composition (Enhanced)
Description: A two-semester practice-based course that gives learners an extended opportunity to develop university-level writing skills. Advances communication abilities in rhetoric, critical analysis, grammar, and documentation, with emphasis on research-based writing and academic literacy. Essays and exercises are required. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGL 109, ENGL 112 or ENGL 114.

Name: ENGL 112 Studies in Composition
Description: Practice-based approach to writing at the university level. Emphasis is placed on the processes of research-based writing. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGL 112, ENGL 109, or ENGL 114.

Name: ENGL 114 Studies in Composition: Indigenous Perspectives
Description: Practice-based approach to writing at the university level in relation to Indigenous perspectives. Emphasis is placed on the processes of research-based writing. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGL 114, ENGL 109, or ENGL 112.

Name: ENGL 150 Introduction to Literary Genre
Description: Introduction to literature focusing on genres such as poetry, drama, and fiction. Develops skills in interpretation of texts. At least 35% of class time involves practice-based instruction in essay writing and research.

Name: ENGL 151 Critical Studies in Literature
Description: Ways of reading, interpreting, and writing about literature using selected critical approaches, such as formalist, feminist, postcolonial, and psychoanalytical. At least 35% of class time involves practice-based instruction in essay writing and research.

Name: ENGL 153 Readings in Narrative
Description: Study of narrative forms such as life-writing, films, histories, myths, narrative poems, novels, short stories, and songs. At least 35% of class time involves practice-based instruction in essay writing and research.

Name: ENGL 155 Writing and Making Technology in the Humanities
Description: Introduction to digital and technological cultures with a focus on humanities methods, drawing on a range of periods in technological development and critical approaches to studying technology. At least 35% of class time involves practice-based instruction in humanities criticism, prototyping, writing, and research.

Name: ENGL 156 Environmental Literature
Description: Introduction to literature and criticism on the environment. Develops skills in interpretation of texts. At least 35% of class time involves practice-based instruction in essay writing and research.

Name: ENGL 202 Okanagan Syilx Literatures: Concepts and Frameworks
Description: Indigenous perspectives as demonstrated through oral story; Okanagan theory and philosophy through oral story; a systems-based Indigenous Peoples story approach to connection to land, ecology and society. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGL 202 or INDG 202.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of INDG 100, INDG 102.

Name: ENGL 203 Topics in Composition
Description: Examination of published research on a special topic with emphasis on rhetorical features and social contexts. Students will produce a final project that demonstrates their ability to reason, develop ideas, organize, write in an effective style, incorporate research, and revise their work.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156.

Name: ENGL 212 Children's Literature
Description: Historical survey of literature written for and about children, in genres such as poems, short stories, fairy tales, novels, and treatises, covering a full range of modes from didactic to realistic to fantasy. At least 35% of class time involves practice-based instruction in critical analysis, essay writing and research.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156.

Name: ENGL 215 Reading Screens
Description: Film and other screen-based media as narrative, with a focus on both formal and ideological elements. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGL 215 or CULT 210.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156.

Name: ENGL 220 Foundations: Literature in Historical Context 1
Description: Poetry, drama, fiction, and non-fiction prose to the eighteenth century, with attention to the importance of history and changes in form for literary analysis.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156.

Name: ENGL 221 Foundations: Literature in Historical Context 2
Description: Poetry, drama, fiction, and non-fiction prose from the eighteenth century to the present, with attention to the importance of history and changes in form for literary analysis.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156.

Name: ENGL 224 Foundations: Reading Across Borders
Description: Critical intercultural reading approaches, focusing on literature and film from the global South. Emphasis upon ideas of culture, difference, and the relations between reader and text. At least 35% of class time involves practice-based instruction in critical analysis, essay writing and research. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGL 224 or CULT 230.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156.

Name: ENGL 234 Foundations: Indigenous Literature
Description: Survey of Indigenous-authored poetry, drama, fiction, non-fiction prose, and orature in North America, with attention to Indigenous methodologies and major critical trends. At least 35% of class time involves practice-based instruction in critical analysis, essay writing and research. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGL 234 or CULT 250.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156.

Name: ENGL 250 Foundations: Interdisciplinary Theory and Method in Literary Research
Description: Major trends in critical theory, with attention to the applications of theory in literary research. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGL 250 or CULT 275.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156.

Name: ENGL 291 African Literary Canon
Description: Significant texts and authors in modern African literature (in English) covering various regions, histories and cultures of the continent. At least 35% of class time involves practice-based instruction in critical analysis, essay writing and research.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156.

Name: ENGL 306 The Programmed World
Description: Working in the context of fine arts and humanities research, students study and apply programming principles in physical and virtual environments. No Digital Humanities or computing experience required. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGL 306 or DIHU 302.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (3 credits of 100-level CULT, DIHU, ENGL, or FILM 100 and third-year standing.)

Name: ENGL 309A Modern Critical Theory and Interdisciplinary Methods - MDN CRIT THRY
Description: Advanced survey of major trends within critical theory, with attention to issues such as subjectivity and power, the body, culture and imperialism, and social discourse. Recommended for all English Majors. No more than 6 credits in total will be granted for ENGL 309, CULT 371 or any combination thereof.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156. (and third-year standing.)

Name: ENGL 333D Canadian Fiction - TRVL IN CDN LIT
Description: One or more major themes and/or movements in Canadian fiction.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156. (and third-year standing.)

Name: ENGL 344D Topics in Medieval Studies - LIFE/DTH MED LIT
Description: Addresses a range of topics in medieval texts, from genres in medieval literature (such as lyric poetry, romance, and fabliaux) to topics dealing with cultural issues.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156. (and third-year standing.)

Name: ENGL 349A 17th-Century Literature - MILTONREVOLUTION
Description: Study of how literary works reflect and respond to social, political, and religious change in the context of revolution. Popular and polemical works, including advice literature, polemical pamphlets, or political tracts, will inform critical debates on gender, religion, and/or liberty. With different topics this course may be taken more than once for credit.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156. (and third-year standing.)

Name: ENGL 349C 17th-Century Literature - RACE & GENDER
Description: Study of how literary works reflect and respond to social, political, and religious change in the context of revolution. Popular and polemical works, including advice literature, polemical pamphlets, or political tracts, will inform critical debates on gender, religion, and/or liberty. With different topics this course may be taken more than once for credit.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156. (and third-year standing.)

Name: ENGL 352 Shakespeare: Earlier Works
Description: Examines Shakespeare's works before 1599.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156. (and third-year standing.)

Name: ENGL 353 Shakespeare: Later Works
Description: Examines Shakespeare's works after 1599.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156. (and third-year standing.)

Name: ENGL 374A British Literature in the Age of Enlightenment - 18C SATIRE
Description: Examines literary engagements, 1660-1832, with a variety of topics relevant to the advent of modernity. With different topics, this course may be taken more than once for credit.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156. (and third-year standing.)

Name: ENGL 376 Television Studies
Description: The medium of television from a global perspective, and the investigation of how genres in different television broadcast regimes shape content and reception. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGL 376 or CULT 315.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156. (and third-year standing. Recommended: ENGL 215.)

Name: ENGL 377 English-Canadian Screen Culture
Description: Development of English-Canadian screen culture studied by concentrating on various movements, the political economy of Anglo-Canadian screen culture, and televisual and cinematic forms and genres. Focus of the survey is on identity, nationhood, and representation. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGL 377 or CULT 305.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156. (and third-year standing. Recommended: ENGL 215.)

Name: ENGL 379 Colonialism and Decolonization
Description: Comparative analysis of the cultural project of European colonialism, including colonial discourse, resistance, and decolonization in Africa, the Caribbean, South and Southeast Asia, and North America. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGL 379 or CULT 340. ENGL 224 and/or ENGL 250 recommended.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156. (And third-year standing.)

Name: ENGL 384 Human Rights, Literature, and Culture
Description: Critical analysis of representational practices within humanitarian and human rights discourses, including literature, life writing, film, journalism, and marketing. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGL 384 or CULT 346. ENGL 250 and/or ENGL 379 recommended.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156. (And third-year standing.)

Name: ENGL 385 Settler Studies, Literature, and Culture
Description: Approaches to the interdisciplinary field of settler colonial studies in Canadian and comparative contexts in relation to literature, film, and other forms of cultural production. Examines the role of representation, narrative, and discourse in settlement, colonization, and decolonization. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGL 385 or CULT 351.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156. (and third-year standing. Recommended: ENGL 234.)

Name: ENGL 386 Studies in Transatlantic Modernism
Description: Major figures and trends in twentieth-century Modernism before WWII.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156. (and third-year standing.)

Name: ENGL 391 Afropolitan Literature
Description: Contemporary African identities in the age of accelerating globalization.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156. (and third-year standing.)

Name: ENGL 395B Popular Literature - STARWARS
Description: An examination of one or more genres, writers, forms, themes, or major trends in popular literature. May not be taken for credit toward the English major, minor, honours or combined major, or the English concentration in the BA, General Studies. With different topics, this course may be taken three times for credit.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156, APSC 176. (and third-year standing.)

Name: ENGL 395D Popular Literature - FANTASY
Description: An examination of one or more genres, writers, forms, themes, or major trends in popular literature. May not be taken for credit toward the English major, minor, honours or combined major, or the English concentration in the BA, General Studies. With different topics, this course may be taken three times for credit.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156, APSC 176. (and third-year standing.)

Name: ENGL 412A Interdisciplinary Studies in Critical Theory - CONST HYSTERIA
Description: Advanced study of a particular area within critical theory. Topics may include queer theory, critical animal studies, ethics, post-humanism, nationalism. No more than 9 credits in total will be granted for ENGL 412, CULT 470 or any combination thereof.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (3 credits of 300-level ENGL.)

Name: ENGL 445 The Victorian Novel
Description: Developments in the novel from Dickens to Thomas Hardy.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (3 credits of 300-level ENGL.)

Name: ENGL 462C 20th- and 21st-Century British Studies - POCO&BRITFICTION
Description: Selected topics in British Studies.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (3 credits of 300-level ENGL.)

Name: ENGL 473 Studies in Indigenous Literature and Criticism
Description: Topics in Indigenous literature and criticism in North America, including particular periods and individual authors. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGL 473 or CULT 450.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (3 credits of 300-level ENGL.)

Name: ENGL 475B Topics in American Poetry - H D & W STEVENS
Description: Study of particular topics, authors, and/or movements in American poetry.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (3 credits of 300-level ENGL.)

Name: ENGL 495N Directed Studies - COMM. PROJECT
Description: Students will undertake supervised research in a clearly-defined area. This research will lead to a major research paper.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=4
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Fourth-year standing. Students must have a 72% average in all upper-level ENGL courses and a minimum of 15 credits of upper-level ENGL.)

Name: ENGL 497H Fourth-Year Seminar - BLACK INTEL TRAD
Description: A seminar in which students will research aspects of an assigned topic. Enrolment is limited to 15 students, and preference will be given to Honours English students.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: BA-O with one of these specializations: HON ENGL,MAJ ENGL
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Acceptance into the English Honours or Major program; a minimum grade average of 76% in at least 15 credits of upper-level ENGL courses; and permission of the unit.)

Name: ENGL 499 Honours Essay
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students with one of these specializations: HON ENGL
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Entry into the English Honours program.)

Name: ENGL 501 Methodologies: Critical Theory
Description: Examines critical and cultural theory and how it informs current practices of research.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O

Name: ENGL 503 Practices in the Profession of Literary Studies and Related Disciplines
Description: Introduction to the profession's expectations, practices, and responsibilities. Pass/Fail.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O

Name: ENGL 522Q Topics in Genre Studies - VICTORIAN GOTHIC
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O

Name: ENGL 522R Topics in Genre Studies - LIT & MEMORY
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O

Name: ENGL 523U Topics in National/International Literatures and Culture - POCO&BRITFICTION
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O

Name: ENGL 523V Topics in National/International Literatures and Culture - NAT INT LIT CULT
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O

Name: ENGL 525J Studies in Diversity and Identity - BLACK INTEL TRAD
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MASC-O,MED-O,MENG-O,MFA-O,MM-O,MSC-O,MSN-O,MSW-O,PHD-O

Name: ENGL 531A Place and Power - PLACE AND POWER
ENGL 590 Independent Research Paper
Description: Under the direction of a qualified supervisor, the student will propose and write a publishable, article-length research paper (7,500 words) on a subject and body of texts of interest to the student. Required for all M.A. coursework students.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O

Name: ENGL 599 Master's Thesis
Description: Under the direction of a qualified supervisor, the student will propose and write a 15,000 to 20,000-word thesis of publishable quality, addressing a subject and body of texts of interest to the student and supervisor. Required for all M.A. thesis students. Pass/Fail.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O

Name: ENGR 303 Engineering Project Management
Description: Project management including initiating, planning, executing, controlling, and closing engineering projects. Managing the scope, costs, schedule, risks, and human resources in engineering projects. External party engagement, including Indigenous communities.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of APSC 169, APSC 201.

Name: ENGR 305 Engineering Economic Analysis
Description: Cost concepts, accounting, time value of money; depreciation and taxes; public sector projects; economic evaluation techniques; handling uncertainty; sustainability in economic evaluation; societal context; infrastructure management needs; project impacts, mitigating risk. Case studies.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: BASC-O in year: >=2
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Second-year B.A.Sc. standing.)

Name: ENGR 310 Fluid Mechanics II
Description: Differential conservation, equations and solutions, boundary layers, compressible flows, and introduction to turbomachinery.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: APSC 253.

Name: ENGR 315 Systems and Control
Description: Dynamic systems, linear systems, control concepts, block diagrams, transient response, root locus, frequency response, Bode and Nyquist plots, and controller design.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: APSC 246.

Name: ENGR 320 Electromechanical Devices
Description: Three-Phase AC power systems. DC and AC magnetic circuits, transformers, DC machines, principles of electromagnetic devices, synchronous machines, induction motors, and brushless DC motors.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: APSC 255.

Name: ENGR 325 Civil Engineering Materials
Description: Structures and properties of common materials: aggregates, Portland cement, concrete, asphalt, timber, composites, and metals. Relationships between materials structures and mechanical properties.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: APSC 259.

Name: ENGR 327 Reinforced Concrete Design I
Description: Analysis of reinforced concrete members subjected to flexure, shear, and combined bending and axial forces. Design of one-way slabs, beams, and short columns. Serviceability analysis. Bond and anchorage.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of APSC 259, APSC 260, APSC 261.

Name: ENGR 330 Reliability and Risk Analysis for Civil Engineering
Description: Applied probability and simulation for civil engineering infrastructure. Methods for probabilistic risk and reliability analysis. Risk-based decision making.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of APSC 254, APSC 258.

Name: ENGR 331 Infrastructure Management I
Description: Introduction to asset management, municipal infrastructure systems, performance and prioritization measures, data management, life cycle costing, decision support tools, integrated approach.

Name: ENGR 332 Surveying and GIS Analysis
Description: Theory and application methods for measuring and representing objects of interest on, below, and over the earth's surface, and for analyzing data to meet engineering design and operational objectives driven by socio-economic or environmental concerns of natural and engineered systems.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of APSC 169, APSC 254.

Name: ENGR 335 Transportation Engineering
Description: Analysis, planning, design, and operation of transportation systems, including: governance, economics, land use, transport modes, users, roads, freeways, end-of-trip facilities, public transit, and intersection controls.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: APSC 254.

Name: ENGR 340 Soil Mechanics
Description: Geological processes, soil classification, principle of effective stress, seepage analysis, shear strength, soil compaction, consolidation, and slope stability analysis.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of APSC 253, APSC 260.

Name: ENGR 341 Engineering Hydrology
Description: Hydrologic processes, climate change and hydrologic cycle analysis, urban flood management. Emphasis on quantitative techniques.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of APSC 253, APSC 254.

Name: ENGR 342 Open Channel Flow
Description: Channel characteristics, flow classification, specific energy and momentum, uniform flow, critical flow, hydraulic jump, flow control structures, channel design, unsteady flow, contaminant transport.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: APSC 253.

Name: ENGR 347 Environmental Engineering
Description: Air, water, environmental pollutants, and treatment design concepts.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of APSC 182, APSC 183, APSC 253.

Name: ENGR 350 Linear Circuit Theory
Description: Transient and steady-state analysis of linear circuits, Laplace transform analysis, mutual inductance and ideal transformers, frequency response and Bode plots, passive and active filters, introduction to synthesis of passive networks, two-port network models for linear systems, and circuit simulation.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of APSC 246, APSC 255.

Name: ENGR 351 Microelectronics I
Description: Signals and amplifier fundamentals, the operational amplifier, diodes, metal-oxide-semiconductor field effect transistor amplifier circuits, and bipolar junction transistor amplifier circuits.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: APSC 255.

Name: ENGR 352 Microelectronics II
Description: Building blocks of integrated-circuit amplifiers; differential multistage amplifiers; frequency response; feedback; output stages and power amplifiers; and operational amplifier circuitry. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGR 352 or ENGR 451.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: ENGR 351.

Name: ENGR 353 Semiconductor Devices
Description: Semiconductor materials, carrier transport phenomena, P-N diode, metal-semiconductor junction, light-emitting diode, semiconductor lasers and photodiodes, bipolar junction transistors, MOSFET, and other semiconductor devices.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: APSC 255.

Name: ENGR 359 Microcomputer Engineering
Description: Microcomputer architecture, number representation, assembly language, parallel and serial input/output, interrupts, memory, peripherals.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: APSC 255.

Name: ENGR 360 Engineering Probability and Statistics.
Description: Set theory, conditional probability, distribution function, functions of random variables, central limit theorem, sample distributions, confidence intervals, elements of parameter estimation and hypothesis testing, testing the fit of a distribution. Applications of probability and statistics in engineering. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGR 360 or ENGR 560.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of APSC 248, APSC 254.

Name: ENGR 362 Digital Signal Processing I
Description: Discrete-time signals and systems, difference equations, sampling and aliasing, decimation and interpolation, quantization errors, z-transform, discrete Fourier transform, fast Fourier transform, implementation of discrete-time systems, finite and infinite impulse response filter design.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: APSC 246.

Name: ENGR 375 Energy System Design
Description: Primary energy sources and carriers. Energy conversion. Analysis of thermal systems. Reacting systems and combustion. Thermal systems design including steam power plants, gas turbines, internal combustion engines, and refrigeration systems.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of APSC 252, APSC 253.

Name: ENGR 376 Materials Science II
Description: Review comprehensive study of phase diagrams, phase transformations, TTT diagrams, heat treatment, ferrous and nonferrous alloys, composite and concrete materials, and materials selection.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: APSC 259.

Name: ENGR 378 Electromagnetics for Engineers
Description: Maxwell's equations, time harmonic fields, plane waves in media, polarization, Fresnel equations, transmission lines, scattering parameters, the Smith Chart, and waveguides.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: APSC 278.

Name: ENGR 380 Design of Machine Elements
Description: Product design methodology; static and fatigue failure theory; design/selection of components including shafts, springs, bearings, gears, brakes, and clutches; design of bolted joints, power screws, and welds; design evaluation and optimization.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: APSC 260.

Name: ENGR 381 Kinematics and Dynamics of Machinery
Description: The design, analysis, and synthesis of mechanisms, linkages, cams, and gear trains; dynamic force analysis; balancing of rotating and reciprocating masses.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: APSC 181.

Name: ENGR 385 Heat Transfer Applications
Description: Steady and transient conduction heat transfer, radiation heat transfer, convection heat transfer, introduction to heat exchanger.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of APSC 248, APSC 252.

Name: ENGR 387 Vibration of Mechanical Systems
Description: Vibration of mechanical systems. Single and multiple degree of freedom systems. Undamped, damped vibrations. Forced vibrations and resonance. Modal analysis, modelling vibrating systems. Spectral analysis. Measurement and control of vibrating mechanical systems.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: APSC 246.

Name: ENGR 401 Bioinstrumentation
Description: Bioinstruments used for tracking vitals, diagnosis, and treatment of disease in the vascular, muscular, nervous, and respiratory systems. Introduction to the fundamentals of each body system, electrical safety, signal acquisition, biosensors, transducers, amplifiers, and analysis of human physiological measurements. Hands on experience with sensors, biomedical devices, and design through labs.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: APSC 254.

Name: ENGR 402 Biotechnology: Fundamentals and Applications
Description: Basics of biotechnology, DNA and RNA technologies, nanobiotechnology, medical biotechnology, and ethics in biotechnology.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing)

Name: ENGR 406 Microelectromechanical Systems
Description: Mechanisms, design, fabrication, and testing of microsensors, actuators, and MicroElectroMechanical systems (MEMS). Credit will not be granted for both ENGR 406 and ENGR 506
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Fourth-year B.A.Sc. standing.)

Name: ENGR 407 Inclusive Design
Description: Design and prototyping of devices from different perspectives of inclusion, with an emphasis on disability, chronic illness, and population diversity; analysis of existing technologies and practices, including built environments, portable devices, user interfaces, sports, and occupational task and process design.

Name: ENGR 408 Energy System Transition
Description: GHG emission reductions, examination of the sources and use of energy, practical potential transition strategies. Participation in a one-day weekend field trip in March is required.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: ENGR 320.

Name: ENGR 409 Construction Digitalization and Informatics
Description: Lean construction; logistics optimization; n-dimensional Building Information Modeling (nD BIM); Internet of Things and Construction 4.0 technologies; new business models; digital fabrication and platform-based construction. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGR 409 or APSC 509.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: BASC-O in year: >=4
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGR 303, MANF 470.

Name: ENGR 411 Technology Entrepreneurship for Engineers
Description: Engineering and innovation, business models, customer development, intellectual property, product development, customer validation, hypothesis testing, company positioning. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGR 411 or ENGR 511.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Fourth-year B.A.Sc. standing.)

Name: ENGR 413 Law and Ethics for Engineers
Description: Ethical theories and their application. The Canadian legal system. Companies, partnerships, independent contractors. Contract documents, specifications, liability, torts and liens. Intellectual property. Agency; evidence; role of an expert witness. Employment law. Professional Governance Act, Code of Ethics, consultation and engagement with Indigenous communities.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: BASC-O in year: =4
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Fourth-year standing.)

Name: ENGR 414 Precast Concrete Structures
Description: Means and methods of precast concrete construction; advanced design of precast concrete structures; analysis of experimental data of precast concrete components; innovations in precast concrete construction. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGR 414 or APSC 514.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: ENGR 325 and ENGR 327.

Name: ENGR 417 Pipeline Integrity Management
Description: Pipeline regulation codes, pipeline integrity management, pipeline operations, materials and fabrication, examination techniques, corrosion protection, and geohazards evaluation.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Fourth-year B.A.Sc. standing.)

Name: ENGR 418 Applied Machine Learning for Engineers
Description: Fundamentals of machine learning, toolboxes in machine learning, supervised learning, unsupervised learning, applications of machine learning in various engineering disciplines. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGR 418 or ENGR 518.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Fourth-year B.A.Sc. standing.)

Name: ENGR 424 Smart Cities
Description: Smart city concept, smart city standardization, smart grid and energy management, Internet of Things and cloud computing for smart city, smart city lighting, intelligent transportation, technology enhanced infrastructure, water solutions, smart buildings and technology, data analytics in smart cities.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Fourth-year B.A.Sc. standing.)

Name: ENGR 425 Design of Steel and Timber Structures
Description: Introduction to limit states design of steel and timber structures: material properties, design of tension and compression members, beams, columns, and connections.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ENGR 325, ENGR 327.

Name: ENGR 426 Analysis of Indeterminate Structures
Description: Analysis of statically indeterminate structures using flexibility and stiffness methods. Linear and non-linear analysis, introduction to finite element method.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of APSC 179, ENGR 327.

Name: ENGR 427 Reinforced Concrete Design II
Description: Design of reinforced concrete two-way slabs, slender columns, footings, and walls. Design for torsion.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ENGR 325, ENGR 327.

Name: ENGR 428 Earthquake Engineering
Description: Strong ground motion; single-degree-of-freedom systems; earthquake response of linear and inelastic systems; subspace iteration; multi-degree-of-freedom systems; earthquake response and design; building design consideration.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: ENGR 327.

Name: ENGR 429 Rehabilitation of Concrete Structures
Description: Concrete damage and deterioration mechanisms, assessment and instrumentation; repair and strengthening materials and techniques; design of structural strengthening systems. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGR 429 or ENGR 529.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ENGR 325, ENGR 327.

Name: ENGR 432 Infrastructure Management II
Description: Impact of climate change, integrated asset management, resilient infrastructure, condition assessment and performance modeling, in-service monitoring and risk-based evaluation, life cycle cost and benefits analysis, prioritization and optimization, advanced modellling and GIS implementation.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ENGR 303, ENGR 305, ENGR 330, ENGR 331.

Name: ENGR 433 Construction Engineering and Management
Description: Management of the firm: strategic planning, designing, construction, productivity management, and project closure. Project delivery systems: traditional, construction management, and turnkey. Estimating, bidding, and bonding. Project control tools and procedures. Safety and quality control. Project Management. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGR 433 or ENGR 533.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: ENGR 303.

Name: ENGR 436 Transportation Planning
Description: Processes and techniques to facilitate properly integrated land use and transport systems, including: survey and data techniques; trip generation; trip distribution; modal choice; trip assignment; development traffic impact assessment; sustainable transportation strategies; and vulnerable road users. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGR 436 or ENGR 536.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: ENGR 335.

Name: ENGR 438 Rock Mechanics and Rock Engineering
Description: Mechanical properties of intact rock. Rock mass properties and classifications. Structural mapping and stereonets. Rock and rock mass strength criteria. Stresses in rock masses. Rock slope stability analysis. Empirical, analytical, and numerical analysis techniques for underground excavations. Rock support and stabilization. Credit will be granted for only one of ENGR 438 or ENGR 538.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: ENGR 340.

Name: ENGR 440 Foundation Engineering
Description: Empirical and analytical approaches for foundation engineering. Topics include site investigation, lateral earth pressure, ground improvement, design of shallow and deep foundations, and retaining structures.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: ENGR 340.

Name: ENGR 441 Advanced Water Treatment Processes
Description: Theory and design of advanced drinking water treatment processes used for challenging source water conditions including advanced oxidation, membrane filtration, ultraviolet disinfection, and adsorption processes. Discussion of removal of emerging contaminants (e.g. pharmaceuticals), regulated and unregulated disinfection by-products, and current issues in potable water treatment and quality.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: ENGR 447.

Name: ENGR 444 Solid Waste Engineering
Description: Applications of engineering principles and practices to land disposal of hazardous and non-hazardous wastes.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of ENGR 340, ENGR 347.

Name: ENGR 445 Design of Water and Wastewater Conveyance Systems
Description: Identification and evaluation of design solutions for providing a community with adequate water supply, collecting and disposing of stormwater and sewage, and managing excess stormwater flow.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: ENGR 341.

Name: ENGR 447 Design of Processes for Water and Wastewater Treatment
Description: Theory and design of fundamental physical, chemical, and biological unit operations for drinking water and municipal wastewater treatment.
