Name: EPSE 421 Assessment of Learning Difficulties
Description: Current research and best practices on the process of assessment for students with learning difficulties. Restricted to students in the Okanagan School of Education and practicing educators. Pass/Fail.

Name: EPSE 433 Assessment and Positive Behavioural Support in School and Community Settings
Description: Introduces students to the philosophy and methods of behavioural assessment and positive behavioural support with persons who engage in challenging behaviour in school and community contexts. Includes instructional and environmental strategies for preventing and responding effectively to behaviour challenges in educational contexts. Pass/Fail.

Name: EPSE 470F Selected Topics in Inclusive Education - LIT NMRCY PRACT
Description: Course content focuses upon a single topic or competency in inclusive education (e.g., autism, gifted students, ADHD). Topics may differ in each offering to respond to new research or current needs in the field. This course may be repeated with new content. Pass/Fail.

Name: ETEC 559 Creating Technology-Enhanced Learning Environments
Description: Paradigm shifts in education have influenced significant change in learning environments. This course is an inquiry into learning environments (past, present, and future) and explores the learning theories, software, hardware, and instructional strategies that support them.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MED-O

Name: EXCH 373 Applied Science Exchange
Description: For B.A.Sc. students on exchange.

Name: EXCH 580 Student Exchange Program, Graduate
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MASC-O,MED-O,MENG-O,MFA-O,MM-O,MSC-O,MSN-O,MSW-O,PHD-O

Name: EXCH 582 Grad Student Studying Abroad on a Non-UBC Program
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MASC-O,MED-O,MENG-O,MFA-O,MM-O,MSC-O,MSN-O,MSW-O,PHD-O

Name: FILM 100 Introduction to Film Studies
Description: Basic aesthetic, economic, sociological, and technological aspects of film.

Name: FILM 103 Acting for Stage and Screen
Description: An introduction to acting techniques pertaining to the style of psychological realism for stage and screen. Credit will be granted for only one of FILM 103 or THTR 103. [5 hours/week studio]

Name: FILM 261 Video I
Description: Introduction to organizational, technical, creative, and critical skills required in video production. Provides experience in all stages of the production process, including pre-production, production, and post-production. Considers a variety of approaches to video, such as artist videos, music videos, and television productions. Credit will be granted for only one of FILM 261 or VISA 261.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of VISA 106, VISA 108.

Name: FILM 271 Video II
Description: Continuation of FILM 261. Further work on organizational, technical, creative, and critical skills required in video production. Provides experience in all stages of the production process, including pre-production, production, and post-production. Considers a variety of approaches to video, such as artist videos, music videos, and television productions. Credit will be granted for only one of FILM 271 or VISA 271.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of VISA 261, FILM 261.

Name: FILM 303 Narrative Film Production
Description: The theory and practice of producing a short narrative motion picture for the purpose of developing narrative film literacy. Credit will be granted for only one of FILM 303, CULT 303, or THTR 303. CULT 210, THTR 103, CRWR 250, or FILM 100 recommended.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of VISA 106, VISA 261, FILM 261. (and third-year standing or permission of the instructor.)

Name: FILM 371 Digital Documentary Production
Description: Theory and practice from the point of view of producer/writer/director. Course culminates in the creation of a short-form documentary. Credit will be granted for only one of FILM 371 or CULT 317.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of VISA 106, VISA 261, FILM 261. (and third-year standing or permission of the instructor.)

Name: FREN 101 Elementary French I
Description: For the beginner. Prepares students to understand and use familiar everyday expressions and to function in basic situations such as communicating personal details and responding in simple social settings. Corresponds to level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR). Not available to students who have completed French 11 and/or students who have a CEFR level A1. The next level course series available is FREN 103-104.

Name: FREN 102 Elementary French II
Description: Continuation of Elementary French I. Completes level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR). Not available to students who have completed French 11 and/or students who have a CEFR level A1. The next level course series available is FREN 103-104.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (FREN 101 or prior introductory French course at CEFR Level A1.)

Name: FREN 103 Upper Elementary French I
Description: Prepares students to understand and use sentences and frequently used expressions related to their everyday life, such as simple and routine tasks requiring a direct exchange of information. Corresponds to level A2 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR). Not available to students who have completed French 12 and/or students who have a CEFR level A2. The next level course series available is FREN 122-123.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (French 11 or FREN 102 or CEFR Level A1.)

Name: FREN 104 Upper Elementary French II
Description: Continuation of Upper Elementary French I. Completes level A2 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR). Not available to students who have completed French 12 and/or students who have a CEFR level A2. The next level course series available is FREN 122-123.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (FREN 103 or prior introductory French course at CEFR Level A2.)

Name: FREN 122 Intermediate French I
Description: Refinement of reading, writing and speaking skills through the study of contemporary literature and other authentic documents of the French-speaking world. Corresponds to level B1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR). Not available to students who have completed Franais Immersion 12 and/or students who have a CEFR level B1 or higher. The next level course series available is FREN 222-223.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (One of FREN 104, French 12, or CEFR level A2.)

Name: FREN 123 Intermediate French II
Description: Continuation of FREN 122. Not available to students who have completed Franais Immersion 12 and/or students who have a CEFR level B1 or higher. The next level course series available is FREN 222-223.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: FREN 122. (, or prior introductory French course at CEFR Level B1.)

Name: FREN 215 Oral French Practice II
Description: Consists of conversational and listening comprehension activities, review of grammar, and vocabulary expansion exercises. Students will be expected to participate actively in group activities and to give frequent oral presentations. Not available to students who have completed Franais 12 in a Francophone school and/or students who have a CEFR level B2 or higher. The next level courses available are FREN 344 or FREN 345.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of FREN 115, FREN 123. (or French 12 Immersion.)

Name: FREN 222 French Language and Style I
Description: Grammar, vocabulary, composition, language in context. Not available to students who have completed Franais 12 in a Francophone school and/or students who have a CEFR level B2 or higher. To join a FREN 300-level section, contact the instructor on record.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: FREN 123.

Name: FREN 223 French Language and Style II
Description: Grammar, vocabulary, composition, language in context. Not available to students who have completed Franais 12 in a Francophone school and/or students who have a CEFR level B2 or higher. To join a FREN 300-level section, contact the instructor on record.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: FREN 222.

Name: FREN 327B Studies in Cinema - STUD IN CINEMA
Description: Thematic survey of Francophone film considered in a broad cultural context. Topics will vary. With different topics this course may be taken more than once for credit.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: FREN 223.

Name: FREN 338 French Society and Culture
Description: Critical approach to French society considered in a broad cultural context.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: FREN 223.

Name: FREN 345 Techniques of Oral Expression in French II
Description: Further training in formal oral presentation in French. Emphasis on structured expression and oral delivery.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: FREN 215 and FREN 223. (Both FREN 215 and FREN 223, or CEFR level B2 or higher.)

Name: FREN 353 French Grammar
Description: Systematic study of the fundamental principles of French grammar.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: A score more than 65% in FREN 223.

Name: FREN 355 Advanced Composition
Description: Development of essay writing skills in French.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: FREN 353.

Name: FREN 360 The Body in French Literature: 1100-1800
Description: Representations of the body as a focus to the study of literary movements and genres in French literature. Selected works of fiction, drama, and poetry from the middle ages to the end of the eighteenth century are discussed in their historical and literary context.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: FREN 223.

Name: FREN 390 Contemporary Francophone Literature: Global Migrations and Transnational Encounters
Description: Contemporary Francophone literature across Sub-Saharan Africa, North Africa, the Indian Ocean, the Caribbean, Oceania and Asia.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: FREN 223. (or permission from the instructor.)

Name: FREN 420F Selected Topics in French Literature and Culture - WOMEN LITERATURE
Description: Topics vary each time the course is offered. May be taken up to three times for a total of 9 credits.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: FREN 353 and one of FREN 327, FREN 330, FREN 338, FREN 360, FREN 362, FREN 390.

Name: FREN 444 French for Work: Professional Oral Performance
Description: Oral expressions, such as academic and professional presentations, debates, and public speaking. Exposure to regional and foreign French accents through a selection of audiovisual material. Of use to students pursuing careers in teaching or international relations, or applying for graduate programs in French.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) FREN 344 or (b) FREN 345; and one of FREN 327, FREN 330, FREN 338, FREN 360, FREN 362, FREN 390.

Name: FREN 460 17th-Century French Tragedy
Description: French classical tragedies through works of Corneille and Racine. Aesthetic and political forces that helped shape these plays will be examined as well as the relationship between theatre and political power. Works will be studied in their socio-historical context and using current literary criticism. This course takes an interdisciplinary approach, incorporating European visual representations of Baroque and Classical aesthetics to assist with comprehension and analysis of texts.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: FREN 353 and one of FREN 327, FREN 330, FREN 338, FREN 360, FREN 362, FREN 390.

Name: FREN 470 When Women Reclaim the Blind Spots of History
Description: Links between literature, history and gender, through a corpus of contemporary francophone fiction and film about historically marginalized women, including the enslaved and indentured.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: FREN 353 and one of FREN 330, FREN 362, FREN 390.

Name: GEOG 108 Earth Systems: Weather, Climate, and Life
Description: Principles and processes that govern the functions of the atmosphere, hydrosphere, and biosphere. Interactions between these environmental systems and human activity.

Name: GEOG 109 Earth Systems: Landscape Dynamics
Description: Principles and processes that govern the functions of the Earth's lithosphere and terrestrial geomorphology. Interactions between the lithospheric system and human activity.

Name: GEOG 128 Human Geography: Space, Place, and Community
Description: Critical introduction to the study and application of the major themes of human geography, including historical, regional, urban, social, and cultural geographies. Draws upon a range of geographic research methods to investigate geographic phenomena, especially human-environment relations. Not for Science credit.

Name: GEOG 129 Human Geography: Resources, Development, and Society
Description: Introduction to concepts, methods, modes of explanation, and recent critical changes in the study of human geography. Interpretation and explanation of geographic variations arising within contexts of rapidly changing cultural, demographic, economic, political, and social phenomena and their relationship to the environment. Not for Science credit.

Name: GEOG 200 Atmospheric Environments
Description: Physical principles underlying weather and climates. Thermal, moisture, and wind climates at scales from valleys to the globe. Daily weather, air pollution, global change. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 200 or EESC 212.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) GEOG 108 and GEOG 109; or (b) two of EESC 101, EESC 111, EESC 121. (or (c) second-year standing in the Bachelor of Science.)

Name: GEOG 201 Introduction to Research in Sustainability and Geography
Description: Introduces skills required to conduct, critically assess, and present research in geography and sustainability. Develops research skills from problem definition through to design and execution of research projects, including how to identify and categorize scholarly articles; identify research questions; and, collect, analyze, and present data and research findings. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 201, SUST 201, or GEOG 371.

Name: GEOG 205 Introduction to Hydrology
Description: Principles of hydrology at site, watershed, and regional scales. Techniques of measurement and analysis. Emphasizes surface water hydrology of western North America. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 205 or EESC 205.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) GEOG 108 and GEOG 109; or (b) two of EESC 101, EESC 111, EESC 121. (or (c) second-year standing in the Bachelor of Science.)

Name: GEOG 217 Geographies of British Columbia
Description: Human geographies of British Columbia (BC) using a combined thematic and case study approach to understand links between the spatiality and temporality of the province and its current context. Particular emphasis will be on introducing the application of critical and justice-oriented topics, such as racism, colonialism, resource extraction, and labour, as they continue to impact the people and places of so-called BC.

Name: GEOG 222 Geomorphology
Description: Landform assemblages and processes of landscape evolution on Earth. Fundamental concepts, including system equilibrium, thresholds, complex response to external forces, and scale dependency, with application to mountains, rivers, coasts, and glaciated terrain. Laboratory exercises require field work in lab time. Required one-day, weekend trip. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 222 or EESC 222.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) GEOG 108 and GEOG 109; or (b) MATH 100 and EESC 111. (or (c) second-year standing in the Bachelor of Science.)

Name: GEOG 233 Climate Change and Society
Description: Critical exploration of climate change as a physical, social, cultural and political challenge. Approaches major climate change themes of knowledge, causes, impacts, responses and governance from a human geography perspective. Emphasizes critical thinking, local-global connections and social justice.

Name: GEOG 250 Introduction to Urban Geography
Description: Examination of how cities emerge, function, and change. Introduces the city in its historical and geographical perspective, focusing on the complex relationship between economic, political, cultural, and environmental phenomena. Students will complete fieldwork projects examining these urban processes at work.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: GEOG 128.

Name: GEOG 270 Introduction to Cartography and Mapmaking
Description: The theory and practice of cartography and map making; thematic map design techniques; cartographic conventions; spatial data acquisition; cartographic communication; critical cartographies; historical and Indigenous mapping; participatory and cognitive mapping.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of GEOG 108, GEOG 109, GEOG 128, GEOG 129.

Name: GEOG 271 Geographic Data Analysis
Description: Introduction to descriptive and inferential statistical analysis in geography and Earth sciences. Topics include descriptive statistics, elementary probability, statistics for spatial analysis, hypotheses testing, analysis of variance, correlation, and regression.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (6 credits of 100- or 200-level courses in GEOG or EESC.)

Name: GEOG 290 Introduction to the Geography of Canada
Description: Selected topics in human geography focusing on the regional distribution of natural resources, population, urban systems, and economic activities.

Name: GEOG 304 Anthropogenic Climate Change
Description: Mechanisms of anthropogenic climate change and its impact on the atmosphere, hydrosphere, cryosphere, and oceans since the Industrial Revolution. Use of computer models to forecast 21st century climate changes. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 304 or EESC 304.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of GEOG 108, GEOG 200, EESC 212. (Third-year standing.)

Name: GEOG 314 Environmental Impact Assessment: Process, Regulation and Administration
Description: Legal, administrative and project management aspects of environmental impact assessment (EIA). EIA regulations, processes and systems. Assessment approaches and methods for cumulative effects, social/economic impacts, strategic and regional assessment, risk assessment and public participation. Canadian federal, territorial and provincial EIA systems. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 314 or EESC 314.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Either (a) 6 credits of EESC or (b) 6 credits of GEOG. Third-year standing.)

Name: GEOG 316 Geography of Natural Hazards
Description: The role of physical and biological hazards, human ecology, environmental perception and world social and political order in explaining the risk of natural disasters. Assessment of acceptable risk, disaster relief and reconstruction, and contrasts between developed and developing nations.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) GEOG 108 and GEOG 109; or (b) two of EESC 111, EESC 205, EESC 212, EESC 222, GEOG 200, GEOG 205, GEOG 222. (Third-year standing.)

Name: GEOG 317 The Physical Environment of British Columbia
Description: The biophysical processes that are shaping and have shaped B.C. Characteristic associations between landforms, climate, soil, and vegetation; biophysical constraints on air, land, and water use.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of EESC 205, EESC 212, EESC 222, GEOG 200, GEOG 205, GEOG 222. (Third-year standing.)

Name: GEOG 351 Urban Social Geography
Description: Introduction to the social geographies of cities. Draws on critical social and cultural theories. Gentrification, racialization in the city, gendered spaces, class segregation, urban form, and cultural geographies of urban life.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of GEOG 128, GEOG 129. (and third-year standing.)

Name: GEOG 353 Geographies of Migration and Settlement
Description: Theoretical and applied perspectives on international migration and settlement. Analysis of international regimes regulating migration, changes in global demographies, immigration policies of nation states, international migration patterns, settlement policies and outcomes.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of GEOG 128, GEOG 129. (and third-year standing.)

Name: GEOG 354 Urban Canada: Growth, Form, and Structure
Description: Patterns and processes of urban growth, spatial structure and organization of the Canadian city, land development and suburbanization, urban core densification, inner city revitalization, consumption and production spheres, quality of life. Emphasis will be on medium-sized cities.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of GEOG 128, GEOG 129. (and third-year standing.)

Name: GEOG 356 Stratigraphy and Sedimentology
Description: Origin, classification and interpretation of sediments and sedimentary rocks. Weathering, erosion, transportation, sedimentation, and lithification of clastic materials. Non-clastic sediments. Sedimentary environments, facies and stratigraphic methods. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 356 or EESC 356.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of EESC 121, EESC 222, GEOG 222.

Name: GEOG 358 Gender, Place, and Culture
Description: Examination of the ways in which genders and geographies are mutually constituted. Exploration of the relationship between socially constructed gender relations and geographic concepts of culture, space, place, nature, and landscape. Gendered nature of everyday space, work, education, and the natural environment.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Two of GEOG 128, GEOG 129, SUST 104.

Name: GEOG 359 Culture, Space, and Politics
Description: Focuses on the cultural turn in geography. Draws upon recent critical theories from cultural studies and cultural geography. Examines the cultural politics of everyday spaces and places.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of GEOG 128, GEOG 129. (and third-year standing.)

Name: GEOG 365 Parks and Outdoor Recreation
Description: Geographic dimensions of parks and outdoor recreation are examined in urban and rural environments. Understanding parks evolution includes focus on the location, distribution, and site capability of parks and recreational resources, including application of ecological, amenity resource, and management models of parks and outdoor recreational facilities.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Two of GEOG 128, GEOG 129, SUST 104.

Name: GEOG 367 Energy Resources Management
Description: Key energy systems and resources management from both global and Canadian perspectives. Supplies, distribution, consumption, resilience and sustainability of energy resources. Alternative energy sources, conventional and unconventional fossil fuels, energy production and delivery systems. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 367 or EESC 367.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of GEOG 108, GEOG 129, EESC 101, EESC 111. (Third-year standing)

Name: GEOG 423 Development of Environmental Thought
Description: An examination of attitudes that have influenced land use and environmental change in the past and present.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Two of GEOG 128, GEOG 129, SUST 104.

Name: GEOG 445 Political Ecology
Description: Critical, interdisciplinary approach to human-environment relations, development and environmental change. Theoretical insights across geography and anthropology with empirical insights from the Global South and Global North. Power, political economy, struggle over meaning, marginality, conflict and social justice in understanding environmental change across scales. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 445 or ANTH 445.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of GEOG 128, GEOG 129, ANTH 100, SUST 104. (Third-year standing.)

Name: GEOG 451 Urban Planning
Description: Urban and regional planning issues from a geographical perspective. Definition of community and its spatial expression in contemporary urban settings, institutional urban planning legislation, history of Canadian planning practice, contemporary urban and community planning practices, relationships between interests of community stakeholders and municipal decision-making process.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of GEOG 128, GEOG 129. (and third-year standing.)

Name: GEOG 454 Geography of Housing
Description: Topics focused on the Canadian city, including current housing markets, neighbourhood change, market failures and housing problems, social housing, and the role of government and policy.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of GEOG 128, GEOG 129. (and third-year standing.)

Name: GEOG 458 Population Geography
Description: The relationship between population growth, demographic changes, urbanization, and the environment. Demographic patterns, mortality, fertility and state policy, economic development, migration and immigration, planning, and policy issues.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of GEOG 128, GEOG 129. (and third-year standing.)

Name: GEOG 460 Critical Geographies of the Anthropocene
Description: Examines how capitalism, colonialism, and associated structural power dynamics have contributed to the geological era 'the Anthropocene'. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOG 460 or GEOG 491O.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) two of GEOG 128, GEOG 129, SUST 104 or (b) one of SOCI 228, ANTH 345. (Third-year standing.)

Name: GEOG 474 Qualitative Research in Human Geography
Description: Theoretical aspects, principles, and methods of qualitative research in human geography.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing. GEOG 371 highly recommended.)

Name: GEOG 498D Directed Studies in Geography - RSRCH DESIGN GEO
Description: Students will undertake a supervised investigation which will result in a written report of the findings. The topic will be agreed upon by the supervising faculty member, the student, and the department head.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing, and permission of the relevant unit head and the supervising faculty member.)

Name: GEOG 498V Directed Studies in Geography - URBNZTN IN CAN
Description: Students will undertake a supervised investigation which will result in a written report of the findings. The topic will be agreed upon by the supervising faculty member, the student, and the department head.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing, and permission of the relevant unit head and the supervising faculty member.)

Name: GEOG 498Y Directed Studies in Geography - URBAN VIS GEOG
Description: Students will undertake a supervised investigation which will result in a written report of the findings. The topic will be agreed upon by the supervising faculty member, the student, and the department head.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing, and permission of the relevant unit head and the supervising faculty member.)

Name: GEOG 498Z Directed Studies in Geography - UR PLAN THEORY
Description: Students will undertake a supervised investigation which will result in a written report of the findings. The topic will be agreed upon by the supervising faculty member, the student, and the department head.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing, and permission of the relevant unit head and the supervising faculty member.)

Name: GERM 100 Beginners' German I
Description: Introduction to the language. Ability to communicate accurately in a variety of everyday situations.

Name: GERM 110 Beginners' German II
Description: Introduction to the language. Ability to communicate accurately in a variety of everyday situations, speak about past events, and express ideas and hypotheses in German.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: GERM 100.

Name: GERM 200 Intermediate German I
Description: Competence and fluency in everyday situations; ability to report and narrate past events fluently and to express opinions; familiarity with contemporary issues in the German-speaking societies.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (One of German 12, GERM 110.)

Name: GERM 210 Intermediate German II
Description: Competence and fluency in everyday situations; ability to report and narrate past events fluently and to express opinions; familiarity with contemporary issues in the German-speaking societies; introduction to German for professional purposes.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: GERM 200.

Name: GISC 380 Fundamentals of Geographic Information Science I
Description: Spatial data representation; raster and vector models; spatial database structure; coordinate reference frames and projections; spatial statistics; metadata and data standards; associated technologies and data sources. Laboratory exercises require ArcGIS. Credit will be granted for only one of GISC 380, GEOG 370, GEOG 380, or EESC 380.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: GISC 381 Fundamentals of Geographic Information Science II
Description: GIS, remote sensing, GPS; geostatistics, spatial analysis, and neighbourhood analysis; visualization, 3D rendering, and animation; principles of geocoding; online mapping and open-source GIS; applied project and workflow management. Laboratory exercises require ArcGIS. Credit will be granted for only one of GISC 381, GEOG 381, or EESC 381.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of GISC 380, EESC 380, GEOG 380.

Name: GISC 480 Practical Applications in GIS
Description: Application of GIS principles and tools in a problem solving context. Case studies are used as the basis for student projects, emphasising data sourcing, data analysis, decision-support, and project management skills. Laboratory and term projects require ArcGIS.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of GISC 381, EESC 381, GEOG 381.

Name: GWST 100 Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Power I: An Introduction
Description: Cross-cultural and historical antecedents to gender studies and feminist thought. The social construction of knowledge and inequality through gender, race, sexuality, and class; the cultural and structural forces that create the dynamic for change and resistance in the personal and political realms of gendered lives.

Name: GWST 110 Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Power II: Everyday Life
Description: Applying the conceptual frameworks learned in GWST 100, considers how gender, race, sexuality and power shape social inequalities in such realms as health, violence, poverty, and work. GWST 100 recommended.

Name: GWST 215 Gender and Popular Culture
Description: Examines how gender, sexuality and race intersect with representation in a variety of genres in popular culture. Considers the production, content, and reception of media texts. Ideological, institutional, social, and personal implications of these representations, and use of media to provoke change.

Name: GWST 223 Critical Sexuality Studies
Description: Overview of the historical emergence of critical sexuality studies. Sexological, psychoanalytic, Foucauldian, feminist, and queer theories of sexuality and gender will be examined. 6 credits of 100-level GWST recommended.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=2
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Second-year standing.)

Name: GWST 235 Laughing Feminisms: Gender and Humour
Description: A survey of theory and humour from second-wave feminism to the contemporary moment, with special attention to women's comedy in literature, performance, and film.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=2

Name: GWST 240 Communication in Gender, Women and Sexuality Studies
Description: Practice-based writing course designed to further develop communication skills in genres and media integral to Gender, Women and Sexuality Studies. Attentive to the dynamic relationship between knowledge and power, the course will focus on analysis and communication in written, visual, oral, mixed media, and digital modes.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=2
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of ENGL 109, ENGL 112, ENGL 114, ENGL 150, ENGL 151, ENGL 153, ENGL 154, ENGL 155, ENGL 156.

Name: GWST 272 Feminism and Environment
Description: Feminist theories and practice to understand and address environmental change. Role of decolonial, antiracist, disability justice and queer feminist perspectives in environmental justice, policy, art, and activism. Credit will be granted for only one of GWST 272 or CULT 272.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (6 credits of GWST, CULT, SUST 104.)

Name: GWST 323 Feminist Epistemologies: Gender, Science, and Knowledge
Description: Introduces foundations of feminist theories of knowledge. Examines critiques of the gendering of scientific knowledge and the relationship between scientific knowledge and social inequality. 6 credits of 100-level GWST recommended.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: GWST 333 Perspectives on Gendered Bodies
Description: Interdisciplinary overview of approaches to gendered embodiment at the level of lived experience and of representation. Focus on the relationship of embodiment to social identity. GWST 100 and GWST 110 recommended.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: GWST 334 Feminist Research Methodologies
Description: Involves the study of the literature of feminist scholarship from a variety of disciplines illustrating the plurality and complementarity of feminist methods.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of GWST 323, GWST 335. (, and third-year standing.)

Name: GWST 340 Writing the Self: Theory and Practice
Description: Life writing with a focus on gender. Critical analysis and the production of narrative in such genres as memoir, autotheory, autoethnography, and critical poetics. Credit will be granted for only one of GWST 340 or CULT 370.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing or permission of the instructor.)

Name: GWST 419 Gender, Dress, and Fashion: Histories and Theories
Description: Overview of historical and theoretical perspectives on the gendered development of dress and the modern fashion system. Consideration of the relationship of identity and adornment. 6 credits of 100-level GWST recommended.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: GWST 430 Femininities
Description: Overview of theoretical and historical constructs of femininity in industrial and post-industrial society. Emphasis on multiple femininities and negotiations of feminine identity. 6 credits of 100-level GWST recommended.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: GWST 491A Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
Description: Individualized reading or research project on an assigned topic in Gender, Women and Sexuality Studies, under the direction of a faculty member. Independent reading and analysis, and a major term paper.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing; 6 credits of GWST; permission of the Department.)

Name: GWST 495U Topics in Women's Studies - QUEER MEMOIR
Description: This course focuses on a selected topic in women's studies. Content will vary from year to year. Consult course listings for current year's offering. With permission of the Gender, Women and Sexuality Studies program advisor, students may receive credit for this course more than once.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing and 6 credits of GWST.)

Name: GWST 495V Topics in Women's Studies - QUEER REALITY TV
Description: This course focuses on a selected topic in women's studies. Content will vary from year to year. Consult course listings for current year's offering. With permission of the Gender, Women and Sexuality Studies program advisor, students may receive credit for this course more than once.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing and 6 credits of GWST.)

Name: HEAL 100 Introduction and Principles of Health and Wellbeing
Description: Broad introduction to health studies as it applies to principles of health and wellbeing with particular emphasis on student health. A review of education and research on a variety of student health issues, and their larger impact, will be investigated and discussed. Opportunities to develop skills and resources for optimal health as it relates to life and academic success are included. Credit will not be granted to use toward the Bachelor of Human Kinetics degree.

Name: HEAL 101 Mental Health in Social Contexts
Description: Social frameworks used to understand mental health and wellbeing of individuals, families and communities.

Name: HES 100 Foundations of Health and Exercise Sciences
Description: The importance of exercise, fitness, physical activity, healthy eating, and other health behaviours across the lifespan. Principles of basic exercise prescription, fitness appraisal, behaviour change, and other positive health approaches; implications for personal health/quality of life, professional success, health care. Formerly offered as HMKN 100. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 100 or HMKN 100.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Registration limited to students in the B.H.E.S. program.)

Name: HES 101 Human Physiology I
Description: Human physiology from the cellular to the systemic level including cellular function, metabolism, the neuromuscular system, and the cardiorespiratory systems. Credit will only be granted for one of HES 101, HMKN 190 or BIOL 131.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Registration limited to students in the B.H.E.S program.)

Name: HES 102 Biomechanics
Description: Application of the elementary principles of physics and math to quantitative analysis of human movement. Analysis will also focus on the development of forces within muscles and their effect on initiating and controlling human movement (pertaining to exercise, physical activity, and rehabilitation). Formerly offered as HMKN 101. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 102 or HMKN 101.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Registration limited to students in the B.H.E.S. program.)

Name: HES 105 Exercise Physiology I
Description: Acute and chronic changes observed in physiological systems as a result of exercise and exercise training. Aerobic and anaerobic metabolism during exercise and cardiovascular, respiratory and muscular responses to physical activity. Formerly offered as HMKN 200. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 105 or HMKN 200.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) HES 100 or (b) HMKN 100; and either (a) HES 101 or (b) HMKN 190.

Name: HES 111 Human Physiology II
Description: An introduction to human physiology from the cellular to the systemic level.This course will examine the gastrointestinal system, the neuroendocrine system, renal function, immune function, the integumentary system, reproduction and special senses. Credit will only be granted for one of HES 111, HMKN 191 or BIOL 133.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: HES 101.

Name: HES 120 Introduction to Human Anatomy
Description: Introduce students to the basic structure and functional relationships of human anatomy in relation to movement. Specific structures include neural, muscular and skeletal systems.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Registration limited to students in the B.H.E.S program.)

Name: HES 130 Social Determinants of Health
Description: Examining the relationships between biological, psychological, social, and economic factors to understand inequities in health outcomes for different individuals and populations. Formerly offered as HEAL 200. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 130 or HEAL 200.

Name: HES 131 Exercise Psychology
Description: Psychological theories and research related to exercise adoption, maintenance, and avoidance. Psychological antecedents and consequences of exercise behaviour. Formerly offered as HMKN 201. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 131 or HMKN 201.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) HES 100 or (b) HMKN 100.

Name: HES 200 Introduction to Nutrition
Description: Application to health promotion and disease prevention including the study of macro- and micronutrients, their functions, absorption, and metabolism in the body. Examination of healthy food sources and eating habits to support health and wellbeing. Credit will only be granted for one of HES 200, HMKN 323 or HINT 331.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) HES 100 or (b) HMKN 100.

Name: HES 201 Exercise Prescription
Description: Exercise prescription and testing for both the healthy adult population and for special populations or persons with a disability. Credit will only be granted for HES 201 or HMKN 311.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of HES 105, HMKN 200 and one of HES 111, HMKN 191; and HES 120.

Name: HES 202 Human Motor Behaviour I
Description: Processes and structures underlying the production human movement. Sensory, motor and cognitive factors influencing the learning, execution, and control of action will be addressed. Formerly offered as HMKN 202. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 202 or HMKN 202.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) HES 101 or (b) HMKN 190; and either (a) HES 102 or (b) HMKN 101; and either (a) HES 111 or (b) HMKN 191.

Name: HES 203 Lifespan Physical and Motor Development
Description: Principles governing physical growth and motor development related to physical activity. Lifespan changes, including aging, and their impact on physical activity participation and performance. Formerly offered as HMKN 203. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 203 or HMKN 203.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) HES 100 or (b) HMKN 100; and either (a) HES 101 or (b) HMKN 190; and either (a) HES 111 or (b) HMKN 191.

Name: HES 211 Exercise Testing
Description: The theory, practice and analysis of safe and effective health, fitness, physiological and lifestyle assessments, including the design, implementation and analysis of standard protocols.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of HES 101, HES 105, HES 111.

Name: HES 212 Exercise Training, Conditioning and Rehabilitation for Health, Fitness and Performance
Description: The theory, practice and analysis of safe and effective exercise training, including the design, implementation and analysis of exercise sessions, training and rehabilitation programs and ongoing monitoring strategies.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of HES 101, HES 105, HES 111.

Name: HES 231 Exercise Counseling and Behaviour Modification
Description: Application of evidence-informed behavior change techniques to help individuals adopt and adhere to health behaviors. Credit will only be granted for one of HES 231 or HMKN 316.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) HES 131 or (b) HMKN 201.

Name: HES 240 Health Research Methods
Description: Introduction to the research methods commonly encountered in health research, including quantitative and qualitative designs; provides a basis for comprehending more fully the research literature relevant to health studies. Formerly offered as HMKN 206. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 240 or HMKN 206.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: BHES-O,BHK-O in year: >=2
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) HES 100 or (b) HMKN 100. (and second-year standing in the B.H.E.S or B.H.K.)

Name: HES 305 Exercise Physiology II
Description: Oxygen transport and vascular response during exercise in humans. Regulation and adaptation of the cardiovascular and respiratory systems during exercise. Formerly offered as HMKN 310. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 305 or HMKN 310.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) HMKN 200 or (b) HES 105.

Name: HES 311 Pathophysiology
Description: The physiological basis of selected cardiovascular, muscular, respiratory, and nervous system disorders, and their effects on health and exercise. Formerly offered as HMKN 335. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 311 or HMKN 335, BIOL 231, BIOL 235 or HINT 231.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) HES 105 or (b) HMKN 200; and either (a) HES 202 or (b) HMKN 202.

Name: HES 320 Functional Anatomy
Description: Functional aspects of human anatomy with special attention to musculoskeletal, vascular, and neural systems that support integrated human movement. Credit will only be granted for one of HES 320 or HMKN 391.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: HES 120.

Name: HES 321 Laboratory Techniques in Exercise Science
Description: Current methods in exercise science will be demonstrated via modules presented by faculty in their areas of specialization including electrophysiological techniques and methods of assessing blood-flow, respiratory capacity, and muscle function. Formerly offered as HMKN 312. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 321 or HMKN 312.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of HES 305, HMKN 310. (Registration is limited to students in the Kinesiology & Allied Health Concentration in the B.H.E.S. Program.)

Name: HES 322 Physical Activity and Health Promotion
Description: Design and implementation of health promotion strategies in a variety of arenas, particularly health promotion/education strategies aimed at encouraging physical activity. Formerly offered as HMKN 322. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 322 or HMKN 322.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of HMKN 100, HES 100 and one of HEAL 200, HES 130 and one of HMKN 201, HES 131.

Name: HES 331 Motivational Interviewing
Description: Study of behaviour change techniques with a particular focus on motivational interviewing, used in one-to-one behavioural support interactions. The course will instill knowledge of theory as well as applied skills in behaviour change counselling. Credit will be only be granted for one of HES 331 or HMKN 495N.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of HES 231, HES 232.

Name: HES 332 Advanced Theories of Health Behaviour Change
Description: Advanced theories in health and exercise psychology and their critical evaluation regarding utility for instilling and sustaining health behaviour change. Formerly offered as HMKN 421. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 332 or HMKN 421.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) HES 232 or (b) HMKN 316. (Registration is limited to students in the Health Behavior Change Concentration in the B.H.E.S. Program.)

Name: HES 333 Health Program Evaluation
Description: Introduction to the key concepts and methods used in evaluation of health programs. Formerly offered as HMKN 303. Credit will be granted for only one of HMKN 303 or HES 333.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) HES 100 or (b) HMKN 100; and either (a) HES 131 or (b) HMKN 201. (Registration is limited to students in the Health Behavior Change Concentration in the B.H.E.S. Program.)

Name: HES 336 Tissue Injury and Repair
Description: The mechanics of both injury and repair of muscular, connective and nervous tissue in acute and chronic conditions. Formerly offered as HMKN 336. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 336 or HMKN 336.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of HMKN 391, HES 320.

Name: HES 340 Methods of Data Analysis
Description: Introduction to basic statistics and methods relevant to the analysis and interpretation of quantitative data pertaining to health and social well-being. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 340, HMKN 205 or STAT 121.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) HES 240 or (b) HMKN 206.

Name: HES 351 Clinical Exercise Physiology
Description: Integrative approach to normal and abnormal responses to exercise as well as the physiological effects of chronic conditions and their clinical management in exercise physiology.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of HES 250, HES 311. (Registration limited to students in the Clinical Exercise Physiology concentration of the B.H.E.S program.)

Name: HES 380 Exercise Metabolism
Description: The underlying metabolic events associated with exercise and nutritional challenges. Substrate delivery and skeletal muscle metabolism with respect to exercise. Formerly offered as HMKN 313. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 380 or HMKN 313.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) HMKN 200 or (b) HES 105; and either (a) HES 200 or (b) HMKN 323.

Name: HES 383 Physical Dimensions of Aging
Description: Changes in physiological function with age. For students planning to become health professionals. Various dimensions of life, including health and functional capacity, are addressed. Formerly offered as HMKN 331. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 383 or HMKN 331.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) HES 105 or (b) HMKN 200; and either (a) HES 203 or (b) HMKN 203.

Name: HES 401 Community Placement Experience
Description: Practical work experience in a supervised health/human kinetics related work setting with a cooperating agency, private business, or industry. No more than 9 credits in total will be granted for any combination of HMKN 401, HMKN 402, HMKN 499. Formerly offered as HMKN 401. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 401 or HMKN 401. Pass/Fail.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: BHK-O in year: >=4
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of HMKN 205, HES 240 and one of HMKN 206, HES 340. (and fourth-year standing in Human Kinetics and permission of the Undergraduate Chair.)

Name: HES 402 Advanced Community Placement Experience
Description: Advanced 'hands-on' practical work experience in a supervised health-related work setting with a partnered organization. Formerly offered as HMKN 402. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 402 or HMKN 402.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of HMKN 401, HES 401. (and permission of both the Practicum Coordinator and the Undergraduate Chair.)

Name: HES 454 Clinical Exercise Physiology Applications in Chronic Conditions: Respiratory Disease
Description: Clinical considerations of respiratory diseases. Safe and effective implementation of exercise programs for people with respiratory disease. Critical review of evidence, standards and recommendations for the use of exercise in the management and prevention of respiratory disease.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: HES 351. (Registration limited to students in the Clinical Exercise Physiology concentration of the B.H.E.S.)

Name: HES 471 Professional Ethics in Health and Exercise Sciences
Description: Ethical and legal responsibilities of allied health practitioners in care and service to clients, patients and public relating to codes of conduct, consent, trust, confidentiality, standards of care, negligence, record keeping, beneficence, least harm, dignity and scope of practice. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 471 or HMKN 400.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: HES 371.

Name: HES 480 Concussion
Description: Investigation of the diagnosis, deficits and treatment of concussion, and the neurocognitive, biomechanical, cerebrovascular, and sensorimotor effects of the injury. Formerly offered as HMKN 404. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 480 or HMKN 404.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: BHK-O,BHES-O in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) HES 240 or (b) HMKN 206; and either (a) HES 311 or (b) HMKN 335; and either (a) HES 340 or (b) HMKN 205.

Name: HES 483 Environmental Physiology
Description: Regulation and adaptation of the cardiovascular, circulatory, and respiratory systems during environmental extremes. Formerly offered as HMKN 411. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 483 or HMKN 411.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of HES 305, HMKN 310.

Name: HES 485 Advanced Circulatory Physiology
Description: Regulation and adaptation of the circulatory systems at rest, during exercise. Focus on adaptations and prescription implications following pathology. Formerly offered as HMKN 414. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 485 or HMKN 414.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) HES 240 or (b) HMKN 206; and either (a) HES 305 or (b) HMKN 310; and either (a) HES 311 or (b) HMKN 335; and either (a) HES 340 or (b) HMKN 205.

Name: HES 486 Muscle Fatigue
Description: Physiological mechanisms within the central nervous system and muscle fibres which contribute to muscle fatigue. The influence of various factors (e.g., sex, age, disease) on muscle fatigue. Formerly offered as HMKN 415. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 486 or HMKN 415.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) HES 240 or (b) HMKN 206; and either (a) HES 305 or (b) HMKN 310; and either (a) HES 321 or (b) HMKN 315; and either (a) HES 340 or (b) HMKN 205.

Name: HES 488 Cortical Control of Movement
Description: Cortical events associated with sensation and motor planning associated with goal-directed movement. Particular focus on plasticity associated with disease and injury. Formerly offered as HMKN 413. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 488 or HMKN 413.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) HES 202 or (b) HMKN 202; and either (a) HES 240 or (b) HMKN 206; and HES 340 and HMKN 205.

Name: HES 490A Project in Health and Exercise Sciences - PROJECT IN HES
Description: Provides opportunities to perform research pertaining to a chosen area of Human Kinetics as agreed upon by a faculty member and student. No more than 6 credits in total of HES 490.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) HES 240 or (b) HMKN 206; and either (a) HES 340 or (b) HMKN 205. (Permission of the School of Health and Exercise Sciences.)

Name: HES 490B Project in Health and Exercise Sciences - PROJECT IN HES
Description: Provides opportunities to perform research pertaining to a chosen area of Human Kinetics as agreed upon by a faculty member and student. No more than 6 credits in total of HES 490.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) HES 240 or (b) HMKN 206; and either (a) HES 340 or (b) HMKN 205. (Permission of the School of Health and Exercise Sciences.)

Name: HES 490C Project in Health and Exercise Sciences - PROJECT IN HES
Description: Provides opportunities to perform research pertaining to a chosen area of Human Kinetics as agreed upon by a faculty member and student. No more than 6 credits in total of HES 490.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) HES 240 or (b) HMKN 206; and either (a) HES 340 or (b) HMKN 205. (Permission of the School of Health and Exercise Sciences.)

Name: HES 492 Undergraduate Honours Thesis
Description: A research problem in health and exercise sciences under the supervision of a Health and Exercise Sciences faculty member. Students engage in research requiring a written report with a public presentation of the findings. Formerly offered as HMKN 449. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 492 or HMKN 449.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: BHK-O with one of these specializations: HON ****
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Restricted to students in the B.H.E.S. Honours Program.)

Name: HES 495D Special Topics in Health and Exercise Sciences - TRND CND HLTH CR
Description: Formerly offered as HMKN 495. Credit will be granted for only one of HES 495 or HMKN 495.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) HES 240 or (b) HMKN 206; and either (a) HES 340 or (b) HMKN 205. (Permission of the School of Health and Exercise Sciences.)

Name: HES 505 Quantitative Analyses: Decision Making Using Data in Health and Exercise Science
Description: How to analyze and interpret statistical data commonly encountered in health and exercise science research. Content includes the choice of appropriate statistical analyses, cleaning data, correlation, linear regression, multiple and logistic regresssion, t-tests and analyses of variance.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MASC-O,MED-O,MSC-O,PHD-O

Name: HES 506 Research Methods in Health and Exercise Sciences
Description: Principles of research methods including philosophy of science, research designs, ethical considerations, critical analysis, qualitative and quantitative approaches, proposal development.

Name: HES 515 Advanced Neuromuscular Physiology and Sensorimotor Neuroscience
Description: Neuromuscular and neuroanatomical processes involved in the control of muscle contraction and movement. Special emphasis on physiological adaptations within the nervous and muscular systems as a result of acute (e.g., exercise, fatigue, injury, hypoxia) and chronic (e.g., training, age, disease) perturbations.

Name: HES 535 Advanced Integrative Human Physiology I
Description: Human oxygen uptake, transport mechanisms and the coordination of physiological systems.

Name: HES 545D Special Topics in Health and Exercise Sciences - METHDS PHYS/META
Description: Credit will be granted for only one of HMKN 495 or HMKN 545 when the subject matter is of the same nature.

Name: HES 545S Special Topics in Health and Exercise Sciences - ADV RESPPHYSPATH
Description: Credit will be granted for only one of HMKN 495 or HMKN 545 when the subject matter is of the same nature.

Name: HES 545W Special Topics in Health and Exercise Sciences - EX/DIET INTERVT2
Description: Credit will be granted for only one of HMKN 495 or HMKN 545 when the subject matter is of the same nature.

Name: HES 545X Special Topics in Health and Exercise Sciences - QUANT TECHNIQUES
Description: Credit will be granted for only one of HMKN 495 or HMKN 545 when the subject matter is of the same nature.

Name: HES 545Y Special Topics in Health and Exercise Sciences - EXERC & SPIN INJ
Description: Credit will be granted for only one of HMKN 495 or HMKN 545 when the subject matter is of the same nature.

Name: HES 545Z Special Topics in Health and Exercise Sciences - ENGR BAL/END EXC
Description: Credit will be granted for only one of HMKN 495 or HMKN 545 when the subject matter is of the same nature.

Name: HES 549 M.Sc. Thesis
Description: Pass/Fail.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MED-O,MSC-O,MASC-O,MA-O

Name: HES 649 Ph.D. Dissertation
Description: Pass/Fail.
Restrictions:
This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: PHD-O -OR-
in one of these programs: MA-O

Name: HINT 110 Applied Research in Health
Description: Basic statistical concepts and procedures with the goal of developing statistical literacy in health care contexts. Includes how descriptive and inferential statistical methods are used to interpret nursing research.

Name: HINT 231 Pathophysiology for Health Sciences
Description: Basic pathophysiology associated with selected diseases and disorders that are commonly encountered by health practitioners in Canada. Pathophysiology, etiology, as well as some of the signs and symptoms, diagnostic tests and treatments currently associated with each disorder. Credit will be granted for either HINT 231 or HKMN 335.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of BIOL 131, BIOL 133.

Name: HINT 320 Global Health
Description: Emerging health issues and trends, evidence-informed approaches and ethical concerns within the context of the global health and global healthcare. Credit will be granted for only one of HINT 320 and NRSG 320 or HEAL 307.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing)

Name: HINT 331 Nutrition for Health Sciences
Description: Introduction to the dietary requirements of nutrients and their related sources, metabolism, and functions. Nutrition in the context promoting health, preventing disease, and managing illness will be the focus, incorporating tools and knowledge about healthy food choices and dietary habits based on scientific evidence. Current nutritional issues will also be discussed.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of BIOL 131, BIOL 133.

Name: HIST 110 Survey of the Ancient World
Description: Survey of ancient history from the first civilizations in the Near East to the fall of Rome. Includes examinations of the ancient civilizations of Mesopotamia, Egypt, Greece, and Rome.

Name: HIST 111 Modern United States History
Description: Survey of the major economic, political, and social developments from the Civil War to the present.

Name: HIST 112 Canadian Lands and Peoples
Description: The people, places, and events central to the development of Canada from Indigenous settlement to the twenty-first century.

Name: HIST 115 World History from First to Second World War
Description: Study of the emergence of the contemporary world from the origins of World War I to the aftermath of World War II.

Name: HIST 118 History of Science, Medicine, and Technology from Antiquity
Description: History of science, medicine, and technology and society from antiquity to the eighteenth century. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 118 or HIST 215.

Name: HIST 126 Europe from the French Revolution
Description: Survey of the development of Europe through the political, social, and industrial revolutions that accompanied the age of European imperialism. Examination of the World Wars and their impact on the decline of Europe.

Name: HIST 145 Contemporary World History
Description: Events and forces shaping the world since the mid-twentieth century.

Name: HIST 151 Modern Latin American History
Description: Survey of the major economic, political, and social currents in Latin America from independence to the present.

Name: HIST 160 Introduction to Asian History
Description: Major economic, political, and social currents in Asian history.

Name: HIST 222 Canadian State and Economy
Description: Economic and political development of the Canadian nation state from Indigenous-settler contact to the twenty-first century. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 222 or HIST 122.

Name: HIST 300 History of Indigenous Peoples of Canada to 1876
Description: The Indigenous people (status and non-status) of Canada from contact to the passage of the Indian Act in 1876. Topics include government policies, environment, gender, religion, oral narratives, colonial frontiers, disease, fur trade.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (6 credits of HIST and third-year standing; or 3 credits of HIST, INDG 100, and third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 301 History of Indigenous Peoples of Canada Since 1876
Description: The Indigenous people (status and non-status) of Canada from the passage of the Indian Act in 1876 to the present. Topics include government policies, environment, gender, religion, oral narratives, activism, urbanization, identity.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (6 credits of HIST and third-year standing; or 3 credits of HIST, INDG 100, and third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 302 Classical Greece and the Mediterranean World
Description: Development of state formation, collective government, citizenship, art, literature, and international relations in the eastern Mediterranean world from ca. 700 to 338 BCE.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: HIST 110.

Name: HIST 304 The Rise and Fall of the Roman Republic
Description: Roman political, social, and economic history from the eighth century BCE to the end of the Republic in 27 BCE. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 304 or HIST 382G.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: HIST 110.

Name: HIST 306 French North America to 1699
Description: French-speaking peoples of North America: Acadians, Franco-Qubcois, French-Canadians, and Cajuns. Focus on North American Atlantic Coast, Acadia, Florida and the St. Lawrence and Great Lakes from 1534-1699. Deals extensively with French-Amerindian relations. Introduction to the historiography of French North America. Students who have received credit for HIST 307 prior to W2022 cannot receive additional credit for HIST 306.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 112, HIST 211 and third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 307 French North America 1699 to 1803
Description: Historical background for understanding the French-speaking peoples of North America: Acadians, Franco-Qubcois, French-Canadians, and Cajuns. Focus on Louisiana, Illinois and the North American interior from 1699-1803. Deals extensively with French-Amerindian relations. Introduction to the historiography of French North America.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 112, HIST 211 and third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 317 History of Southern Africa
Description: Pre-colonial, colonial, and contemporary history emphasizing South Africa.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 115, HIST 145 and third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 336 Eastern Europe During the Cold War
Description: A political, social, and cultural history of Eastern Europe from the end of the Second World War to the fall of state socialism.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Either (a) one of HIST 115, HIST 126 and third-year standing or (b) 6 credits of HIST.)

Name: HIST 344 Stuart England, 1603-1714
Description: Study of the changes in politics, economics, and the empire from James I to Queen Anne and Robert Walpole.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (6 credits of HIST; or HIST 116 and third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 373 History of Gender, Race, and Science in the Atlantic World
Description: The rise of scientific theories of racial and sexual difference and their role in the creation of the early modern Atlantic world (1500-1800), including its economy, culture, and socio-political order.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 118, HIST 218 and third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 375 History of Pandemics
Description: Select pandemics in the history of medicine and their impact on society, culture, politics, and the economy.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 118, HIST 218 and third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 382A Special Topics in Political History - MID EASTERN HIST
Description: Students should consult the department for the particular topics offered in a given year.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (3 credits of HIST and third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 383A Special Topics in Social and Cultural History - CDN SETTLER COL
Description: Students should consult the department for the particular topics offered in a given year.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (3 credits of HIST and third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 384 Commodities in Africa
Description: Examines the history of commodity production (agricultural, mineral, oil, and other resources) on the African continent from the late nineteenth century to the present day with attention to how commodities have shaped and continue to influence the development of the continent and inform its political, social and economic encounters.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 115, HIST 145 and third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 385 China and Europe in Africa since 1900
Description: Examines the actions of China in Africa in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries as a form of new economic imperialism, following from earlier nineteenth and twentieth century European imperialism in Africa. Considers the responses of African states and the West to China's expansion on the African continent. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 385 or HIST 381 when the subject matter is of the same nature.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 115, HIST 145 and third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 395 Environmental History of North America
Description: Themes and methods of environmental history, focusing primarily on North America from the sixteenth to the twenty-first centuries.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (3 credits of HIST and third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 396 History of India, 1800-1914
Description: Examines developments of Indian society and culture under the British Raj during the period of 1800-1914, the consolidation of British power in nineteenth-century India, and early Indian resistance to imperial rule.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (6 credits of HIST; or HIST 115 and third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 418 Capitalism in Canada
Description: History of capitalism and political-economy in Canada.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 443 20th-Century Russia
Description: Examines the significance of the Great Patriotic War; the last years of Stalin, the tempering of Stalinism in the Khrushchev years; Gorbachev's failed revolution; the collapse of the Soviet Union; and Russia in transition.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 126, HIST 145 and third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 444 Slave Societies in the Americas
Description: Comparative analysis of the institution of chattel slavery, its growth, its effects on slaves and masters, its relation to the larger society, and the causes of its decline in the various cultures of the Americas.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 211, HIST 240 and third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 452 History of Mexico Since 1810
Description: Mexican history since independence including church-state relations, struggles for land and social justice, state formation, class and gender relations, and the role of popular culture. OUC equivalent: HIST 452.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 151, HIST 240, HIST 241 and third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 460A Topics in Technology and Society in History - REPROD TECH
Description: Historical dimensions of current debates about technology, focusing on a single, interdisciplinary theme.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (3 credits of HIST and HIST 118; or HIST 218 and third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 468 International Relations of the Great Powers of the 20th Century to 1939
Description: International relations of Britain, France, Germany, Russia, and the United States from the beginning of the 20th century until 1939. Political and diplomatic settlements between the Paris Peace Conference of 1919 and the German invasion of Poland in 1939.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 115, HIST 126 and third-year standing; or 6 credits of POLI and third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 469 International Relations of the Great Powers of the 20th Century from 1939
Description: International relations of Britain, France, Germany, Russia, and the United States since 1939. Emphasis upon the emergence, course, and end of the Cold War. Great Powers in decolonization and the end of empires.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 145, HIST 126 and third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 473 War and Society from the 18th to 20th Centuries
Description: Continuity and change in the relations of war and society, and the connections between the economy, society, the military, and government in peacetime and war; not a course in military history.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (6 credits of HIST; or one of HIST 115, HIST 116, HIST 126, HIST 145 and third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 492 History, Theory, and Method
Description: Explores selected problems and issues in the theory and practice of historical work. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 492 or IGS 592.
Restrictions:
This course is restricted to students with one of these specializations: MAJ HIST -OR-
with one of these specializations: HON HIST
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (6 credits of HIST or third-year standing. Open to non-history majors with permission of the department head.)

Name: HIST 495C Special Topics in History - VICTORIAN BRIT
Description: Examination of selected topics and issues in history. With different topics, this course may be taken more than once for credit.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (12 credits of HIST.)

Name: HIST 497 Digital Media and History
Description: An introduction to digital media history and the application of digital methods to historical inquiry, interpretation, and communication.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: HIST 499 Undergraduate Honours Thesis
Description: Research and writing of a thesis paper under the supervision of a History faculty member. Participation in scheduled colloquia and seminars is required. Restricted to students in the Honours Program (third-year standing; minimum 12 credits of History; minimum grade average of 76% in all attempted History courses; and minimum overall average of 72%).
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students with one of these specializations: HON HIST

Name: IGS 524A Proseminar in Interdisciplinary Studies - IGS PROSEM A
Description: This seminar-based course prepares graduate students to excel in their academic, professional and scholarly pursuits by engaging topics related to professionalism and scholarly communication. May be offered for 1, 2 or 3 credits; program requirements for the IGS MA, MSc and PhD programs require completion of 3 credits in total. Restricted to students in the IGS MA, MSc, or PhD program. Pass/Fail.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MASC-O,MED-O,MENG-O,MFA-O,MSC-O,MSN-O,MSW-O,PHD-O

Name: IGS 530B Special Topics in Creative and Critical Studies - LIT & MEMORY

Name: IGS 582 Indigenous Knowledges Theme Seminar
Description: Theoretical background on Indigenous Knowledges and Indigenist research. Focuses on a range of strategies and principles for research on or through Indigenous languages and culture. Restricted to students in the Indigenous Knowledges Theme.

Name: IGS 583 Urban and Regional Studies
Description: Theory and methodologies for understanding urban and regional studies. Topics include urban, regional and rural policy issues.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MASC-O,MED-O,MENG-O,MFA-O,MSC-O,MSN-O,MSW-O,PHD-O

Name: IGS 584 Sustainability Theme Seminar
Description: Introduction to the challenges and opportunities of interdisciplinary sustainability research, including problem framing, research methods and socio-ecological applications from contributing disciplines.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MASC-O,MED-O,MENG-O,MFA-O,MSC-O,MSN-O,MSW-O,PHD-O

Name: IGS 585 Knowledge Mobilization and Sustainability Policy
Description: Exploration of opportunities and constraints to translating interdisciplinary sustainability research into effective social action. Approaches to implementing sustainability to be considered include: political and legal frameworks; federal and provincial policy forums; corporate social responsibility; First Nations environmental stewardship challenges; and sustainability in education and the arts.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MASC-O,MED-O,MENG-O,MFA-O,MSC-O,MSN-O,MSW-O,PHD-O

Name: IGS 586A Community Engagement, Social Change, and Equity Theme Seminar - COMM ENG SOC EQ
Description: Will provide the necessary theoretical background on Community-Based Participatory Research (CBPR). Students will learn about a range of strategies and principles of CPBR; advantages and limitations of this approach; skills necessary for participating effectively in CBPR projects.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MASC-O,MED-O,MENG-O,MFA-O,MSC-O,MSN-O,MSW-O,PHD-O

Name: IGS 587 Global Politics, Culture and Theory
Description: Examination of conceptual approaches to Global Studies.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MASC-O,MED-O,MENG-O,MSC-O,MSN-O,MSW-O,PHD-O

Name: IGS 588 Global Studies Panorama
Description: Introduction to interdisciplinary and collaborative approaches to the field of Global Studies.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MASC-O,MED-O,MENG-O,MFA-O,MSC-O,MSN-O,MSW-O,PHD-O

Name: IGS 589 Governance
Description: Frameworks of governance systems and public policy.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MASC-O,MED-O,MENG-O,MFA-O,MSC-O,MSN-O,MSW-O,PHD-O

Name: IGS 590 Power and Ideas
Description: Exploration of the complex relations between power, knowledge and ideas.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MASC-O,MED-O,MENG-O,MFA-O,MSC-O,MSN-O,MSW-O,PHD-O

Name: IGS 591 Society and Conflict
Description: Utilizing social theory to analyze conflict and inequality.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MASC-O,MED-O,MENG-O,MFA-O,MSC-O,MSN-O,MSW-O,PHD-O

Name: IGS 592 History, Theory, and Method
Description: Explores selected problems and issues in the theory and practice of historical work. Credit will be granted for only one of IGS 592 or HIST 492.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MASC-O,MED-O,MFA-O,MSC-O,MSN-O,MSW-O,PHD-O

Name: IGS 593 Decolonizing the Global: Contemporary Ethnography and Postcolonial Theory
Description: An examination and close reading of global issues drawing on ethnography and postcolonial theory.

Name: IGS 599B Master's Thesis - MASTER'S THESIS
Description: Pass/Fail.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MASC-O,MED-O,MENG-O,MFA-O,MSC-O,MSN-O,MSW-O,PHD-O
