Name: SECH 400 Applied Health Economics
Description: Methods to assess efficiency of health-related programs; theoretical and practical empirical methods for conducting, analyzing and interpreting applied economic evaluations in the context of health and healthcare. Credit will be granted for only one of SECH 400 or SECH 500.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: SECH 500 Applied Health Economics
Description: Methods to assess the efficiency of health-related programs; theoretical and practical empirical methods for conducting, analyzing and interpreting applied economic evaluations in the context of health and healthcare. Credit will be granted for only one of SECH 400 or SECH 500.

Name: SOCI 111 Introduction to Sociology
Description: Studies how society influences human behaviour. How is society organized and structured? How does it affect the way we think and act? What is the relationship between individuals and society? What is our social nature? Why is there inequality in the world?

Name: SOCI 209 Foundations of Sociological Thought
Description: Foundational ideas in the historical development of sociological thought. Ways in which these ideas have influenced new generations of sociologists.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 111.

Name: SOCI 226 Work, Technology, and Social Change
Description: Relationship between work, technological innovation, and social change. Emphasis on industrial and communications revolutions. Effects of technology on work, social stratification, family, gender identity, and politics.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 111.

Name: SOCI 228 Sociology of the Anthropocene
Description: Examination of the "Anthropocene" at the intersections of the environment, colonialism, racialization, gender, and species. Explores the drivers of the Anthropocene, the politics of naming and dating an epoch after humans, as well as environmental justice and Anthropocene futures. Credit will only be granted for one of SOCI 228 or SOCI 295E.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 111.

Name: SOCI 246 Sociology of Sports
Description: Key concepts and theoretical ideas in the sociology of sport. Relationships between sports and socialization, intersectional inequalities (race, class, gender, ability), deviance and violence, health and injuries, politics and social movements, media, nationality and the environment.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 111.

Name: SOCI 249 Crime and Society
Description: Introduction to crime as a social phenomenon. Changing definitions of crime in relation to social and political change; scope and nature of crime; criminalization; growth of criminology; institutional responses to criminal behaviour by the justice system.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 111.

Name: SOCI 263 Political Sociology
Description: Social and economic basis of political power. State and inter-state relations; ideology and control; alienation and anomie; political movements and social revolutions; political violence and terrorism; the political economy of world conflict. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 263 or SOCI 463.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) SOCI 111 or (b) POLI 100 or (c) all of HIST 115, HIST 145.

Name: SOCI 291 Fundamentals of Sociological Research
Description: Overview of quantitative and qualitative research designs and methodologies. Topics include sampling, operationalization, ethics, data collection and analysis, scientific and sociological literacy. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 291 or SOCI 271.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 111.

Name: SOCI 295A Current Topics in Sociology - SOCI OF RELIGION
Description: Examination of selected topics in contemporary sociology. Consult with the department for current offerings. This course may be taken more than once but with different topics.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 111.

Name: SOCI 295V Current Topics in Sociology - SCI TECH MEDICAL
Description: Examination of selected topics in contemporary sociology. Consult with the department for current offerings. This course may be taken more than once but with different topics.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 111.

Name: SOCI 305 Sociology of Families
Description: Theoretical and methodological approaches to family structures and relations.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 111. (and third-year standing.)

Name: SOCI 309 Violence in Intimate Relations
Description: Social, historical, cultural, and political roots of violence in intimate relations. Primary focus on women, children and the elderly.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 111. (and third-year standing.)

Name: SOCI 330 Sociology of Tourism
Description: Critical analysis of the global tourist industry and the tourist experience; impact of tourism on communities and labour; relationship between tourism and leisure.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 111. (and third-year standing.)

Name: SOCI 362B Social Inequality - SOC INEQUALITY
Description: Structural and interactional approaches to relations of power that (re)produce inequality with a focus on the intersections of race, class, gender, and sexualities.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 111. (and third-year standing.)

Name: SOCI 374 Sexuality, Law, and Society
Description: Examination of how sex and sexuality are regulated through law. Topics may include the social and legal regulation of family forms, pornography, sex work, sexually transmitted infections, sexual violence, and the interplay of technology and law through topics such as online dating.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: SOCI 376 Classical Sociological Theory
Description: Classical sociological theories and their relationship to methodological issues. Emphasis on the procedures by which sociological explanations are made. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 376 or SOCI 375.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 209. (and third-year standing.)

Name: SOCI 377 Contemporary Sociological Theory
Description: Contemporary sociological theories and their relationship to methodological issues. Emphasis on the procedures by which sociological explanations are made.Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 377 or SOCI 375.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 376. (and third-year standing.)

Name: SOCI 395 Sociological Methods: Qualitative Research
Description: Examination of methods such as ethnography, interviewing, historical and discourse analyses. Theoretical, epistemological, and ethical issues in social research and methods.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 111. (and third-year standing.)

Name: SOCI 411B Special Studies in Canadian Society - SP STD CDN SOC
Description: Advanced analysis of issues in Canadian society. Consult the department head for frequency of offering and course topic.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 111. (and third-year standing.)

Name: SOCI 415 Feminist Theory
Description: Development of feminist theories and their relationship to sociology. Social and cultural bases of feminism. Special attention to contemporary debates.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 217. (and third-year standing.)

Name: SOCI 430 Labour in a Global Economy
Description: Relationship between globalization and international labour; impact of global change on the international division of labour; barriers to and possibilities of new organizational strategies for labour solidarity.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 111. (and third-year standing.)

Name: SOCI 432 Sociology of Food
Description: How does food shape social relations (class, gender, race, age)? What is its role in the construction of meaning and identity? How does it connect to the political through civil society and social movements? How is it impacted by globalization? Credit will only be granted for one of SOCI 432 or SOCI 496 when on the same topic.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 111. (and third-year standing.)

Name: SOCI 434A Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
Description: An individualized directed reading and/or research project in sociology under the supervision of a faculty member.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Permission of the department head and faculty member. Students must consult with the department head prior to registration.)

Name: SOCI 465 Nations and nationalisms
Description: Social bases of nationhood. Sociological examination of issues related to national identities and nationalism: theories of nationalism; social roots and implications of national identity and belonging; nationalism and conflict; nationalism, ethnicity, and genocide.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) SOCI 111 or (b) POLI 221 or (c) all of HIST 115, HIST 145. (Third-year standing.)

Name: SOCI 480 Aging, Diversity, and Inequality: Global and Comparative Perspectives
Description: Comparative examination of aging in an era of globalization with a social justice and intersectional perspective. Emphasis on ageism and issues of power for older adults.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 111. (and third-year standing.)

Name: SOCI 492 Surveillance and Society
Description: Surveillance as a social phenomenon, involving differences in power and visibility. How surveillance is related to governance, control, and privacy. Theories and concepts from the interdisciplinary field of surveillance studies, with an emphasis on social relationships. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 492 or SOCI 496V.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 111. (and third-year standing.)

Name: SOCI 496A Advanced Studies in Sociology - DRUGS & SOCIETY
Description: In-depth examination of selected topics in sociology. Topic may change each time the course is offered. Consult the department for frequency of offering and current course topic. Repeatable for up to 9 credits on different topics during a complete program of study.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 111. (and third-year standing.)

Name: SOCI 496D Advanced Studies in Sociology - TRUE CRIME
Description: In-depth examination of selected topics in sociology. Topic may change each time the course is offered. Consult the department for frequency of offering and current course topic. Repeatable for up to 9 credits on different topics during a complete program of study.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 111. (and third-year standing.)

Name: SOCI 496X Advanced Studies in Sociology - SCI TECH MEDICAL
Description: In-depth examination of selected topics in sociology. Topic may change each time the course is offered. Consult the department for frequency of offering and current course topic. Repeatable for up to 9 credits on different topics during a complete program of study.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SOCI 111. (and third-year standing.)

Name: SOCW 511 Introduction to Social Work
Description: An introduction to social work with emphasis on ethical decision making and preparation for professional practice.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students with one of the following versions: FND
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Restricted to students in the M.S.W. program.)

Name: SOCW 512 Theories and Interventions for Clinical Social Work
Description: Advances students' understanding of major theoretical frameworks and treatment modalities for clinical and direct social work practice and their relevance to and application within the planned change process.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students with one of the following versions: FND
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Restricted to students in the M.S.W. program.)

Name: SOCW 513 Assessment Skills for Clinical Social Work
Description: Theoretical perspectives and foundational skills for assessment in clinical social work.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students with one of the following versions: FND
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Restricted to students in the M.S.W. program.)

Name: SOCW 514 Diversity and Critical Reflexive Practice
Description: Meanings, dynamics, and impacts of diversity in social work practice. Students examine their own identities and social locations and a range of theories and orientations to inclusion and social justice.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students with one of the following versions: FND
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Restricted to students in the M.S.W. program.)

Name: SOCW 515 Social Welfare Policy in Canada
Description: Historical and current forces shaping Canadian legislation, policies, programs, and services; impacts of these on social work practice and service users.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MSW-O with one of the following versions: FND
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Restricted to students in the M.S.W. program.)

Name: SOCW 517 Social Work and Indigenous Peoples in Canada
Description: Overview of historical and current issues confronting social work with First Nations, Mtis, and Inuit individuals, families, and communities within Canada including but not limited to child protection; critical assessment of theories for social work practice with Canada's Indigenous peoples.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MSW-O with one of the following versions: FND
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Restricted to students in the M.S.W. program.)

Name: SOCW 518 Integrative Seminar for Field Education
Description: Links classroom education with field education. Consists of independent readings, invited speakers, and online discussions. Pass/Fail.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students with one of the following versions: FND
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Restricted to students in the M.S.W. program.)

Name: SOCW 519 Social Work Field Education I
Description: Development, application, and integration of core social work knowledge and skills in social work practice settings. Pass/Fail.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students with one of the following versions: FND
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Restricted to students in the M.S.W. program.)

Name: SOCW 520 Social Work Practice with Families
Description: Examines major interdisciplinary theoretical perspectives and practice approaches for assessment and intervention with families.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MSW-O
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Restricted to students in the M.S.W. program.)

Name: SOCW 531 Anti-Racist and Anti-Oppressive Clinical Practice
Description: Provides an opportunity to expand theoretical and analytical foundation in the awareness, knowledge, understanding, and skills needed to effectively carry out anti-oppressive social work practice.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MSW-O
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Restricted to students in the M.S.W. program.)

Name: SOCW 540B Selected Topics in Social Work Practice - ADV CLIN PRAC
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MSW-O
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Restricted to students in the M.S.W. program.)

Name: SOCW 540D Selected Topics in Social Work Practice - SBSTNC USE ABSE
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MSW-O
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Restricted to students in the M.S.W. program.)

Name: SOCW 540H Selected Topics in Social Work Practice - MNTL HLTH PRAC
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MSW-O
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Restricted to students in the M.S.W. program.)

Name: SOCW 551 Advanced Clinical Social Work Theory and Practice
Description: Integrates theory and practice with attention to relational principles and a complex analysis of personal and social problems. Consideration of the dynamic interaction between the individual and the social world, and the possibility of intervention at multiple levels.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MSW-O
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Restricted to students in the M.S.W. program.)

Name: SOCW 553 Research Knowledge and Evidence in Clinical Social Work Practice
Description: Knowledge and skills for utilizing empirical evidence to guide clinical social work practice.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MSW-O
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Restricted to students in the M.S.W. program.)

Name: SOCW 554 Mental Health and Mental Illness
Description: Explores relevant mental health issues to social work practice in a broad range of settings. Critically examines social work's role in providing effective, evidence-based, theoretically sound interventions and treatments.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MSW-O
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Restricted to students in the M.S.W. program.)

Name: SOCW 555 Organizations and Leadership
Description: Knowledge of human service organizations and tools for effective leadership. Restricted to students in the M.S.W. program.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MSW-O with one of the following versions: FND

Name: SOCW 558 Advanced Integrative Seminar for Field Education
Description: Integrates theoretical knowledge and practice experience in direct/clinical settings. This course is graded on a pass/fail basis.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Restricted to students in the M.S.W. program.)

Name: SOCW 559 Social Work Field Education II
Description: Provides 2nd year Foundational and Advanced One-Year track students an opportunity to apply and integrate theory and practice in clinical social work practice settings. Pass/Fail.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MSW-O
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Restricted to students in the M.S.W. program.)

Name: SOCW 564 Trauma-Informed Clinical Social Work
Description: Knowledge of trauma, its relevance to assessment and treatment in clinical social work practice.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Restricted to students in the M.S.W. program.)

Name: SOCW 598 Graduating Paper
Description: A scholarly paper in an area of interest that conforms to the demands of a peer-reviewed social work journal. Pass/Fail.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MSW-O

Name: SOCW 599 Thesis
Description: An independent research or scholarly project which aims to develop knowledge and practice implications for clinical social work practice. Pass/Fail.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MSW-O

Name: SPAN 101 Beginners' Spanish I
Description: Development of listening, speaking, reading, and writing in Spanish. Corresponds to the first half of level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR).

Name: SPAN 102 Beginners' Spanish II
Description: Development of listening, speaking, reading, and writing in Spanish. Completes level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR).
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Either (a) a score of 70% or higher in Spanish 11 or (b) SPAN 101.)

Name: SPAN 201 Advanced Beginners' Spanish I
Description: Grammar, introduction to composition, oral practice, and reading. Corresponds to the first half of level A2 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR).
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Either (a) a score of 70% or higher in Spanish 12, or (b) SPAN 102.)

Name: SPAN 202 Advanced Beginners' Spanish II
Description: A continuation of SPAN 201. Grammar, composition, oral practice, and reading. Completes level A2 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR).
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SPAN 201.

Name: SPAN 301 Intermediate Spanish I
Description: Intermediate grammar, composition, oral practice, and reading. Corresponds to the first half of level B1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR).
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SPAN 202.

Name: SPAN 302 Intermediate Spanish II
Description: A continuation of SPAN 301. Intermediate grammar, composition, oral practice, and reading. Completes level B1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR).
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SPAN 301.

Name: SPAN 303 Conversational Spanish
Description: Development of speaking and listening skills through active learning activities and discussions about a variety of topics that may include social media, streaming programs, movies, and current events. Corresponds to level B1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SPAN 202.

Name: SPAN 401 Advanced Spanish I
Description: Advanced grammar, composition, oral practice, and reading. Corresponds to level B2 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR).
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SPAN 302. (or equivalent)

Name: SPAN 402 Advanced Spanish II
Description: Advanced grammar, composition, oral practice, and reading. Corresponds to level B2 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR).
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SPAN 401.

Name: SPAN 427 Interpretation Skills
Description: Development of sight, simultaneous, and consecutive interpretation skills from English to Spanish and vice versa.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SPAN 425.

Name: STAT 121 Elementary Statistics
Description: Descriptive and inferential statistics, elementary probability, probability distributions, estimation of parameters, hypotheses testing, correlation, linear regression. Credit will be granted for only one of STAT 121 or STAT 124.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) a score of 60% or higher in one of MATH 125, MATH 126 or (b) a score of 67% or higher in one of MATH 12, PREC 12.

Name: STAT 124 Business Statistics
Description: Introduction to surveys and simple sampling strategies; descriptive methods for one and two variables; frequency distributions; correlation and regression; descriptive methods for time series and index numbers; and probability and relationship to statistical inference. Good for CA, CMA credit. Credit will be granted for only one of STAT 121, STAT 124.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (One of Principles of Mathematics 11, Pre-Calculus 11, Foundations of Mathematics 12.)

Name: STAT 203 Introduction to Probability
Description: Combinatorics. Axioms of probability. Discrete and continuous random variables, expectation, and variance. Transformations. Central limit theorem and applications. Weak law of large numbers. Credit will be granted for only one of STAT 203 or STAT 230.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: DATA 101 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 142.

Name: STAT 205 Introduction to Mathematical Statistics
Description: Sampling distribution theory. Likelihood. Parameter estimation. Confidence intervals and hypothesis testing; simple regression, analysis of variance and contingency table analysis. Credit will be granted for only one of STAT 205 or STAT 230.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: STAT 203.

Name: STAT 230 Introductory Statistics
Description: Applied statistics for students with a first-year calculus background. Estimation and testing of hypotheses, problem formulation, models and basic methods in analysis of variance, linear regression, and non-parametric methods. Descriptive statistics and probability are presented as a basis for such procedures.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 142 and one of DATA 101, COSC 221, ECON 102.

Name: STAT 303 Intermediate Probability
Description: Multivariate probability distributions, moment and generating functions.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of MATH 200, STAT 203.

Name: STAT 324 Mathematical Finance
Description: Simple and compound interest, discount, force of interest, simple and general annuities, amortization of debts, bonds, depreciation, mortality tables, contingent payments, life annuities, insurance, and an introduction to financial derivatives. Credit will be granted for only one of STAT 324 and STAT 224.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=2
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: MATH 200 and one of STAT 205, STAT 230.

Name: STAT 400 Statistical Communication and Consulting
Description: Development of broad guidelines for a comprehensive approach to data analysis with a focus on communicating statistical ideas from planning experiments to the presentation of results. Topics include criteria for selection of suitable methodologies, data preparation, outlier detection, and exploratory data analysis. Credit will be granted for only one of DATA 500 or STAT 400 when the subject matter is of the same nature.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: All of DATA 311, DATA 315.

Name: STAT 401 Probability and Statistical Inference
Description: Theory of statistical modelling: distributions of data, likelihood-based inference for learning unknown parameters, construction of confidence intervals and development of tests. Bayesian methods will be used to contrast standard statistical procedures.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: STAT 303.

Name: STAT 403 Stochastic Processes
Description: Random walks, Markov chains, Poisson processes, continuous time Markov chains, birth and death processes, exponential models, and applications of Markov chains.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: STAT 303.

Name: STAT 406 Environmetrics
Description: Statistical concepts and methods in environmental science and management. Scientific problem-solving using statistical methods. Integration of the formulation of objectives, study design, and quantitative methods appropriate for the design. The role and use of statistical software packages.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: DATA 310.

Name: STAT 448A Directed Studies in Statistics - DIR STDY STATS
Description: Investigation of a specific topic as agreed upon by the student and the faculty supervisor. Completion of a project and an oral presentation are required. No more than 6 credits of STAT 448 may be taken for credit.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Successful completion of 15 credits of 300- or 400-level MATH and STAT courses; and permission of the department head and faculty supervisor.)

Name: STAT 448B Directed Studies in Statistics - DIR STDY STATS
Description: Investigation of a specific topic as agreed upon by the student and the faculty supervisor. Completion of a project and an oral presentation are required. No more than 6 credits of STAT 448 may be taken for credit.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Successful completion of 15 credits of 300- or 400-level MATH and STAT courses; and permission of the department head and faculty supervisor.)

Name: STAT 448C Directed Studies in Statistics - DIR STDY STATS
Description: Investigation of a specific topic as agreed upon by the student and the faculty supervisor. Completion of a project and an oral presentation are required. No more than 6 credits of STAT 448 may be taken for credit.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Successful completion of 15 credits of 300- or 400-level MATH and STAT courses; and permission of the department head and faculty supervisor.)

Name: STAT 507 Sampling and Design
Description: Collection of data using either designed experiments or survey samples. Planning and practice of data collection. Observational and experimental data pros and cons. Standard methods in survey samples. Experimental design review. Credit will be granted for only one of DATA 407, or STAT 507.

Name: STAT 538 Advanced Statistical Modelling
Description: Least-squares, generalized least-squares and likelihood estimation. Theory and application of parametric and non-parametric regression models such as splines, penalized splines, and generalized additive models. Assessment and treatment of data issues including missingness and measurement error. Credit will be granted for only one of DATA 410, or STAT 538.

Name: STAT 547I Topics in Statistics - ENVIRONMETRICS
Description: Topics chosen from different areas within the field of statistics, such as time series, longitudinal and multi-level modelling, multivariate analysis, machine learning, resampling and permutation methods, smoothing and filtering, survival analysis, sports analytics and spatial statistics. Content will be determined so as to complement course offerings and meet the needs of the students. With the permission of the department head, this course may be taken more than once on a different topic.

Name: STAT 547J Topics in Statistics - PROB & STAT INFR
Description: Topics chosen from different areas within the field of statistics, such as time series, longitudinal and multi-level modelling, multivariate analysis, machine learning, resampling and permutation methods, smoothing and filtering, survival analysis, sports analytics and spatial statistics. Content will be determined so as to complement course offerings and meet the needs of the students. With the permission of the department head, this course may be taken more than once on a different topic.

Name: STAT 547K Topics in Statistics - STAT LEARNING
Description: Topics chosen from different areas within the field of statistics, such as time series, longitudinal and multi-level modelling, multivariate analysis, machine learning, resampling and permutation methods, smoothing and filtering, survival analysis, sports analytics and spatial statistics. Content will be determined so as to complement course offerings and meet the needs of the students. With the permission of the department head, this course may be taken more than once on a different topic.

Name: STAT 560 Probability and Stochastic Processes
Description: Theory of probability, including random variables, expectation, conditional expectation, generating functions, modes of convergence of random variables and their distributions. Applications to random models such as Markov, Poisson, birth-death, Gaussian and diffusion processes.

Name: STMC 331 Language Practice and Pedagogy: Praxis in Different Immersion Contexts
Description: Language acquisition pedagogies in and through practice. The language of instruction is Statimc Language. Restricted to students in the Bachelor of Statimc Language Fluency program.

Name: STMC 332 Language Practice and Pedagogy: Creative, Constructive and Performative Arts
Description: Intensive language immersion class demonstrating, in and through practice, traditional Statimc visual arts. The language of instruction is Sttimcets. Restricted to students in the Bachelor of Statimc Language Fluency program.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: STMC 331.

Name: STMC 351 Language Applications: Numeracy and Math
Description: Numeracy and math frameworks from a Nle?kepmx perspective towards increased proficiency in functional numeracy. The language of instruction is Statimc Language.

Name: STMC 352 Language Applications: Literature and Performative Arts
Description: Emphasis on the language domains of literature and performative arts, and a diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use in these domains. The language of instruction is Statimcets. Restricted to students in the Bachelor of Statimc Language Fluency program.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: STMC 351.

Name: SUST 100 Sustainability: People, Place, and Process
Description: The concept of sustainability and its relationship to people and communities, the management and conservation of natural resources, land and food systems, and the built environment. Guest speakers and in-class discussions covering topics which address local and global contexts. May include community service learning project.

Name: SUST 104 Introduction to Environmental Humanities
Description: Explores the contribution of historical, philosophical, anthropological, and literary scholarship to elucidation and mitigation of a specific environmental issue.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (SUST 100 recommended.)

Name: SUST 200 Application, Practice and Management Approaches
Description: Concepts of governance, natural resource management, and economy-environment connections. Restricted to students in the Bachelor of Sustainability program.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: SUST 100.

Name: SUST 201 Introduction to Research in Sustainability and Geography
Description: Introduces skills required to conduct, critically assess, and present research in geography and sustainability. Develops research skills from problem definition through to design and execution of research projects, including how to identify and categorize scholarly articles; identify research questions; and, collect, analyze, and present data and research findings. Credit will be granted for only one of SUST 201, GEOG 201, or GEOG 371.

Name: SUST 202 Community Service Learning
Description: Apply sustainability learning and knowledge to the broader community through a self-directed project involving at least 30 hours of community service. Restricted to students in the Bachelor of Sustainability program.

Name: SUST 204 Creative Communication and Engagement
Description: Using experiential and collaborative learning, students of sustainability improve their communication skills as speakers, listeners, collaborators, leaders and problem solvers. Credit will be granted for only one of SUST 204 or THTR 204.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (SUST 104 recommended.)

Name: SUST 205 Sustainability Economics
Description: Explores and contrasts approaches and tools from mainstream economics and heterodox economics that may contribute to sustainability decision making. Identification and evaluation of trade-offs associated with choices made in the name of sustainability. Restricted to students in the Bachelor of Sustainability program.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (SUST 200 recommended.)

Name: THTR 101 Performance Improvisation
Description: A physical approach to improvisation as it relates to the creation of live performance events.

Name: THTR 103 Acting for Stage and Screen
Description: An introduction to acting techniques pertaining to the style of psychological realism for stage and screen. Credit will be granted for only one of THTR 103 or FILM 103.

Name: THTR 104 The Art of Public Speaking
Description: Verbal and nonverbal communication skills as well as knowledge of basic communications technologies. Well-suited to students who wish to build skill and confidence in public presentation.

Name: THTR 180 Theatre Appreciation: The Power of Live Performance
Description: Explores how live performances (stand-up comedy, circus, puppetry, performance art, theatre, dance and music) engage an audience and reveal the shifting dynamics of public communication.

Name: THTR 204 Creative Communication and Engagement
Description: Using experiential and collaborative learning, students of sustainability improve their communication skills as speakers, listeners, collaborators, leaders and problem solvers. Credit will be granted for only one of THTR 204 or SUST 204.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (SUST 104 recommended.)

Name: THTR 212 Creativity as Source and Resource
Description: Process-oriented exploration of creativity as a source of personal growth and expressive freedom, and a resource for the cultivation of self-confidence, resilience, and well-being.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Second year standing.)

Name: THTR 280G Devised Public Performance - DVSD PBLC PERFMC
Description: An intensive laboratory course in performance creation leading to a public presentation. Students may work extensively out in the community and compulsory rehearsals will be scheduled outside of class time.

Name: THTR 303 Narrative Film Production
Description: The theory and practice of producing a short narrative motion picture for the purpose of developing narrative film literacy. Credit will be granted for only one of THTR 303, CULT 303, CULT 316 or FILM 303. VISA 106, VISA 261, VISA 271, CULT 210, THTR 103, CRWR 250, or FILM 100 recommended.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: THTR 304 World Theatre and Cultural Performance
Description: Explorations of world theatre and cultural performance traditions and practices from South, Southeast and East Asia; Oceania; Sub-Saharan Africa; the Middle East; and the Americas; includes Indigenous theatre. Credit will be granted for only one of THTR 304 or WRLD 304.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: THTR 309 Performance Art: Global Perspectives
Description: History, theory, and practice of performance art as a visual medium, a global language, and a political force. Explores a wide range of experimental and interdisciplinary performance art practices, including key contributions by Indigenous artists. Credit will be granted for only one of THTR 309, ARTH 309, CULT 309 or CULT 380.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: THTR 411 Performance Studies
Description: Seminar in the interdisciplinary field of performance studies, broadly conceived as the investigation of aesthetic, ritual, and everyday life performance practices. Credit will be granted for only one of THTR 411, CULT 411 or CULT 480.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: THTR 480G Special Topics in Performance Creation - DVSD PBLC PERFMC
Description: An intensive course in performance creation leading to a public presentation. Students may work extensively out in the community and additional compulsory rehearsal time will be scheduled.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: THTR 280. (or permission of the instructor.)

Name: THTR 530 Directed Studies in Theatre
Description: Directed studies course for graduate students in performance. Restricted to students in the M.F.A. program with specialization in Interdisciplinary Studies, or with permission of the Department of Creative Studies.

Name: VGRS 599 Visiting Graduate Research Students
Description: Restricted to visiting graduate students.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in one of these programs: MA-O,MASC-O,MED-O,MENG-O,MFA-O,MM-O,MSC-O,MSN-O,MSW-O,PHD-O

Name: VISA 090 Safety Training
Description: Develops students' competence in using the tools in the woodshop and metalshop through demonstrations and the completion of a small project. This non-credit course is required in order to work in these facilities. Pass/Fail.

Name: VISA 102 Drawing and Two-Dimensional Art Practices I
Description: This foundation course will introduce the principles, practices, and concepts central to drawing and two-dimensional art.

Name: VISA 103 Drawing and Two-Dimensional Art Practices II
Description: Continuation of VISA 102.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 102.

Name: VISA 104 Three-Dimensional Art Practices I
Description: This foundation course will introduce the materials, principles of form and space, and ideas in contemporary 3D art practices.

Name: VISA 105 Three-Dimensional Art Practices II
Description: Continuation of VISA 104.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 104.

Name: VISA 106 Introduction to Digital Media I
Description: Introduces digital media in contemporary art practice through photography, computer imaging, video, and other emerging digital technologies.

Name: VISA 108 Introduction to Digital Media II
Description: Expands on digital media in contemporary art practices through computer imaging, animation, and other emerging digital technologies.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 106.

Name: VISA 137 Introduction to Art I
Description: Survey of art theory and practice for students with little or no previous art experience. A wide range of ideas, approaches, and media will be studied.

Name: VISA 215 Painting I
Description: Introduction to the materials and techniques of painting. Exploration of colour, surface, structure, and space. Students will be encouraged to search for personal imagery. Critical evaluation skills will be developed through individual and group critiques.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 103.

Name: VISA 225 Painting II
Description: Continuation of VISA 215.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 215.

Name: VISA 233 Printmaking: Screenprinting I
Description: Examination of the various processes of screenprinting. Project-based course with considerable emphasis on technical development and skills acquisition. Focus will be on the synthesis of a student's personal imagery and the process of screenprinting.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 103.

Name: VISA 235 Sculpture I
Description: For the student who wishes to specialize in sculpture. Students will examine three-dimensional space through a variety of projects and materials.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 105.

Name: VISA 244 Photography I
Description: Introduction to the basics of photography and darkroom techniques through the use of the camera as an expressive, conceptual, and artistic tool. A 35mm SLR film camera and tripod are required.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of VISA 103, VISA 106, VISA 108.

Name: VISA 245 Sculpture II
Description: For the student who wishes to specialize in sculpture. Students will work with the concepts of space and materials to create personal solutions to problems set by the instructor.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 235.

Name: VISA 253 Printmaking: Screenprinting II
Description: Provides opportunities for students to continue their exploration of the medium of screenprinting. More advanced processes will be introduced, with continued focus on the development of each student's personal imagery.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 233.

Name: VISA 254 Introduction to Printmaking: Etching and Lithography
Description: Introduction to drawing-based printmaking processes - line etching and stone lithography. Focus is on gaining familiarity with these processes and on personal imagery. Basic drawing skills are an asset.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: Either (a) VISA 103 or (b) VISA 147. (or permission of the instructor.)

Name: VISA 255 Introduction to Printmaking: Linocut and Letter Press Printing
Description: Introduction to the printmaking processes - relief printing and text-based letterpress printing. Focus is on gaining familiarity with these processes and on the development of personal imagery. Basic drawing skills are an asset.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of VISA 103, VISA 147. (or permission of the instructor.)

Name: VISA 256 Photography II
Description: A further refinement of photographic and darkroom processing skills emphasizing creative, conceptual, and experimental approaches. A 35mm SLR film camera and tripod are required.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=2
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 244.

Name: VISA 261 Video I
Description: Introduction to organizational, technical, creative, and critical skills required in video production. Provides experience in all stages of the production process, including pre-production, production, and post-production. Considers a variety of approaches to video, such as artist videos, music videos, and television productions. Credit will be granted for only one of VISA 261 or FILM 261.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of VISA 106, VISA 108.

Name: VISA 266 2D Animation
Description: Introduces core principles and techniques required for the creation of two-dimensional digital animation projects.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 108.

Name: VISA 268 Strategies in Digital Art: Visual Communication
Description: Concepts, principles, and techniques to design effective interfaces exploring areas of branding, information architecture and interaction design.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 108.

Name: VISA 269 Strategies in Digital Art: Virtual Worlds
Description: Critical understanding and research-creation of virtual environments employing non-linear storytelling, media aesthetics, modelling, animation, interaction design and coding using 3D modelling software.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 108.

Name: VISA 271 Video II
Description: Continuation of VISA 261. Further work on organizational, technical, creative, and critical skills required in video production. Provides experience in all stages of the production process, including pre-production, production, and post-production. Considers a variety of approaches to video, such as artist videos, music videos, and television productions. Credit will be granted for only one of VISA 271 or FILM 271.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of VISA 261, FILM 261.

Name: VISA 282 Drawing III
Description: Core course in drawing. Various drawing approaches, material applications, and image manipulation practices are explored.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 103.

Name: VISA 283 Drawing IV
Description: Continuation of VISA 282. Extended exploration of various drawing approaches, material applications, and image manipulation practices.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 282.

Name: VISA 300U Advanced Practice in Drawing - ADV DRAWING
Description: To extend students' abilities in mark-making, image production, and expression of meaning through drawing. Emphasis on developing personal visual languages.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 283.

Name: VISA 300V Advanced Practice in Drawing - ADV DRAWING
Description: To extend students' abilities in mark-making, image production, and expression of meaning through drawing. Emphasis on developing personal visual languages.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 283.

Name: VISA 312U Advanced Practice in Painting - ADV PAINTING
Description: Advanced studio course to increase the student's exploration and understanding of painting.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 225.

Name: VISA 312V Advanced Practice in Painting - ADV PAINTING
Description: Advanced studio course to increase the student's exploration and understanding of painting.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 225.

Name: VISA 322U Advanced Practice in Sculpture - ADV SCULPTURE
Description: Advanced studio course to explore contemporary practices in sculpture.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 245.

Name: VISA 322V Advanced Practice in Sculpture - ADV SCULPTURE
Description: Advanced studio course to explore contemporary practices in sculpture.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 245.

Name: VISA 336U Advanced Practice in Printmaking - ADV PRNTMAKING
Description: Opportunity for students to continue their exploration of select media in printmaking (intaglio, relief, lithography, and screenprinting) within the context of contemporary art practice. Interdisciplinary crossover, evolving processes, and new materials will be encouraged.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of VISA 253, VISA 254, VISA 255.

Name: VISA 336V Advanced Practice in Printmaking - ADV PRNTMAKING
Description: Opportunity for students to continue their exploration of select media in printmaking (intaglio, relief, lithography, and screenprinting) within the context of contemporary art practice. Interdisciplinary crossover, evolving processes, and new materials will be encouraged.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of VISA 253, VISA 254, VISA 255.

Name: VISA 362U Advanced Practice in Photography - ADV PHOTO
Description: Advanced studio course in digital- and film-based photography. Emphasis on photography as an artistic tool. No more than 12 credits in total will be granted for VISA 362, CULT 362, CULT 310, or any combination thereof.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 256. (or permission of the instructor.)

Name: VISA 362V Advanced Practice in Photography - ADV PHOTO
Description: Advanced studio course in digital- and film-based photography. Emphasis on photography as an artistic tool. No more than 12 credits in total will be granted for VISA 362, CULT 362, CULT 310, or any combination thereof.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 256. (or permission of the instructor.)

Name: VISA 382U Advanced Practice in Media Arts - ADV MEDIA ARTS
Description: Advanced interdisciplinary course addressing the importance of technology-based approaches in contemporary art with emphasis placed upon the formation of an idea and the media most appropriate to its expression. No more than 12 credits in total will be granted for VISA 382, CULT 382, or any combination thereof.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of VISA 206, VISA 266, VISA 268, VISA 269, VISA 261. (or the permission of the instructor.)

Name: VISA 382V Advanced Practice in Media Arts - ADV MEDIA ARTS
Description: Advanced interdisciplinary course addressing the importance of technology-based approaches in contemporary art with emphasis placed upon the formation of an idea and the media most appropriate to its expression. No more than 12 credits in total will be granted for VISA 382, CULT 382, or any combination thereof.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: One of VISA 206, VISA 266, VISA 268, VISA 269, VISA 261. (or the permission of the instructor.)

Name: VISA 400 Practicum
Description: Students work and learn in certain off-campus, art-related positions to receive credit toward the B.F.A. degree. The department head, the program coordinator, and the course instructor will determine if the activity meets the criteria to qualify for credit.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Completion of two 300-level VISA courses in the area of the proposed practicum activity.)

Name: VISA 482 Advanced Art Practices I
Description: Advanced studio course for fourth-year visual arts students. Students will propose and carry out an independent program of studio work in consultation with course directors and faculty advisors. Students will be intensively involved in artistic research and creation. Interdisciplinary activity will be encouraged. Self-directed readings, writing projects, individual and group critiques, and participation in a final exhibition will be required. Various professional practice topics will be covered.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (12 credits of 300-level studio courses, and a combined minimum grade average of 68% in ARTH 301 and another 3 credit 300- or 400-level ARTH course.)

Name: VISA 483 Advanced Art Practices II
Description: Continuation of VISA 482. As part of the course requirements, students must participate in a graduating exhibition.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 482.

Name: VISA 582 Graduate Studio in Visual Arts I
Description: A studio course for graduate students in Visual Arts. The production of independent artwork and the critical analysis of that work. Students may work in any artistic discipline. Restricted to students in the M.F.A. program with specialization in Visual Arts, or with permission of the Department of Creative Studies.

Name: VISA 583 Graduate Studio in Visual Arts II
Description: The production of independent artwork and the critical analysis of that work. Students may work in any artistic discipline.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: VISA 582. (Or permission of the Department of Creative Studies.)

Name: WRLD 100 A World History of Horror
Description: Introduction to the idea of horror across historical times, geographic regions, and genres, with an emphasis on the interdisciplinary methodologies and theories of World Literature.

Name: WRLD 150 Introduction to Intercultural Communication
Description: Current intercultural communication theories and their critiques. Key concepts are applied to popular culture texts from around the world, providing a context for practice with a variety of intercultural communication skills, development tools, and self-reflective writing techniques.

Name: WRLD 158 Introduction to Language and Culture: Modern Japanese
Description: Introduction to key intercultural and sociolinguistic concepts that affect social interaction in a Japanese-speaking environment, using basic spoken Japanese.

Name: WRLD 159 Introduction to Language and Culture: Modern German
Description: Introduction to German language and to key intercultural and sociolinguistic concepts in German speaking environments. Not available to students with a CEFR level (or equivalent) of A1 or higher.

Name: WRLD 200 Introduction to World Literatures
Description: A thematically organized introduction to world literatures, interconnecting a range of cultures and historical periods. Texts will be studied in English translations.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (3 credits of first year English)

Name: WRLD 304 World Theatre and Cultural Performance
Description: Explorations of world theatre and cultural performance traditions and practices from South, Southeast and East Asia; Oceania; Sub-Saharan Africa; the Middle East; and the Americas; includes Indigenous theatre. Credit will be granted for only one of THTR 304 or WRLD 304.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: WRLD 310 Mythologies in Motion
Description: Literary study of a selection of transcultural myths and their influence across time.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: WRLD 340 Tales of Resistance: Indigenous Voices in Central America
Description: Indigenous literature (including oral traditions, myths, legends, stories, songs testimonial narratives) from Indigenous nations in Southern Mexico and Guatemala. Students may be evaluated in Spanish with instructor's permission. Available for credit towards a Minor in Spanish only for students evaluated in Spanish.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: WRLD 351 Mediterranean World in Cinema and Literature
Description: Changing depictions of the ancient Mediterranean world in media, such as novels, plays, paintings, movies, and television series. Credit will not be granted for both WRLD 351 and WRLD 399f.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=2
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: WRLD 360 Literature and Power
Description: Explores the intersections of literature and power, featuring poems, short stories, and novels from nations as geographically, politically, and ethnically diverse as Iran, North Korea, Cuba, Italy, and Great Britain.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: WRLD 370 Story and Image Across the Islamic World
Description: Selections from the arts of the book across the Islamic world (8th to 19th C) showing how literature inspired painters and calligraphers to weave together word and image. Digital art historical approaches will normally be used, though no computing experience is required. Credit will be granted for only one of ARTH 370, DIHU 370, or WRLD 370.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: WRLD 382 Cross-cultural Travel Narratives
Description: Experiential learning course combining introduction to intercultural communication theory and the literary study of cross-cultural migration narratives.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: WRLD 390 Bollywood in Flux
Description: Contemporary Bollywood film and surrounding debates.
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing or permission from the instructor.)

Name: WRLD 399N Special Topics in World Literatures - MEM & HOLOCASUST
Description: Trans-cultural or cross-regional topics, with a focus on a specific genre and/or historical period. With different topics this course may be taken more than once for credit.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: WRLD 440 From Forests to Oceans: Ecological Cartographies of the "Global South"
Description: Exploration of ecological spaces -- such as oceans, mangroves, deserts, and forests -- through literature emerging from regions popularly known as the "Global South."
Restrictions: This course is restricted to students in year: >=3
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing or permission from the instructor.)

Name: WRLD 482 Voices from the Margins: Minority Writing from Japan
Description: Literary representations of Japanese national identity via an analysis of writing by minority and Indigenous authors from Japan, in English/translation. Credit will be granted for only one of WRLD 399E and WRLD 482.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)

Name: WRLD 497 Community Service Learning
Description: Experiential learning course where volunteer work in a local, regional, or international community organization is combined with guided critical self-reflective writing, critical reading and discussion of related social issues, and the analysis of intercultural and/or interpersonal communication. Consult instructor for a list of the current projects.
Pre-req string: Pre-reqs: (Third-year standing.)
